column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174280,2016,Research Seminar,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. L. van de Grift', 'dr. L.C. Crump', 'prof. dr. I. Tames', 'prof. dr. J. Vijselaar', 'prof. dr. K.E. Sluyterman']",,"Course goals

Through a hands-on approach students learn, first of all, how to turn a general research theme into specific set of questions that can be answered with the available source material. Second, students learn how to organize the actual research, including careful planning and logging of the work they do. Third, students experiment with different forms of reporting of the results of their research, including a literature review, a research report, a poster, and a blogpost.&nbsp

In order to make an independent contribution to research that is both scholarly and socially relevant, students have to learn how to carry out academic research. In Utrecht we believe that, students have to work alongside experienced researchers in order to become a good historians. In this Research Seminar students participate in ongoing research projects of our departmental staff. They assist in the collection and analysis of data from primary and secondary sources.
Poster presentations teach students how to present the results of their highly specialized research to a broader audience.</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174204,2016,Research Seminar AMR: Advanced Medieval History,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. A.C. van Rhijn'],,Course goals
Enabling the student to write a thesis in the field of Medieval History.</body>

During the research seminar students are acquainted with the methods developed in the discipline of Medieval History, with attention to the uses of sources and the debates current among scholars internationally. This is accomplished by the in-depth study of a topic, decided upon in advance.

Students who are required to return to their home university by the end of December, are allowed to complete the course by 'distance learning' (extra assignments, papers etc) in the month of January, receiving 5 ECTS for the course. Students must always make individual arrangements with the course coordinator before the start of the course.</body>
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174949,2016,Research Seminar AMR: Advanced Medieval Literature,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. D.E. van der Poel'],,Course goals
After completing the course the participants:
- have knowledge about the dominant modern approaches to medieval literature and about their merits and weaknesses
- have knowledge about the major genres in the European medieval literature and have read at least one text from each genre
- are able to determine which approach is followed in modern studies about medieval literature and to judge the quality of those studies
- are able to choose an approach which is fitting to answer a specific question about one or more specific medieval literary texts.</body>

This course is a continuation of 'Medieval Literature'. The modern concept 'literature' did not exist in the middle ages. This implies that when modern scholars talk about medieval literature, they are using an anachronistical term. There are several ways to cope with this problem. In this course the advantages and the disadvantages of the various approaches wil be discussed and demonstrated by confronting medieval texts with modern scholarship.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174981,2016,Research Seminar AMR: Language and History II: Celtic II,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['A. Griffith'],,Course goals
• possess in-depth knowledge on the historical phonology of Old Irish and Middle Welsh and the absolute chronology of sound changes
• have facility with the historical phonology from Proto-Celtic to Insular Celtic and from our earliest records in the early Middle Ages to the languages of the High Middle Ages
• can integrate (inner-Celtic and Latin) loanwords into the established framework of historical phonology
• can conduct research on a linguistic topic using available text corpora.&nbsp

This course expands upon the topics covered in block 1. The first way in which that expansion manifests itself is in the temporal domain. While the focus in block 1 was on developments of the 1st millennium, that time-span will be expanded here to focus both on earlier, Proto- or early Celtic changes, as well as later ones found within the attested record, i.e. from Old to Middle Irish and from Old British and Old Welsh to Middle Welsh.

Secondly, this course aims to establish a more rigorous time-frame for the relative chronology of developments established in block 1 by focusing on efforts to produce absolute chronologies of changes. This topic will force us to confront linguistic evidence with evidence from other disciplines, such as epigraphy and history.

Thirdly, since loanwords, both from Latin and from amongst the Celtic languages, offer a means of testing and refining our understanding of the sound changes, we will examine work on loanwords into the early Celtic languages.

Fourthly, and finally, we will examine the ever increasing number of online corpora available for the study of the medieval Celtic languages and explore how these can be exploited for research purposes. This topic will form the basis of the assignment, which will ask students to use available corpora to address an assigned or chosen problem.

This course will help students refine their competency in data analysis as well as enhance their oral and written communicative skills. It will also teach them how to integrate resources made possible through advances in digital humanities into their research.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174961,2016,Research Seminar AMR: Language and History: Celtic I,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['A. Griffith', 'dr. M. O Flaithearta']",,"Course goals
• possess up-to-date knowledge on the historical phonology of Old Irish and Middle Welsh
• can reconstruct forward and backward between Insular Celtic, Middle Welsh, and Old Irish
• can conduct basic research on a linguistic topic&nbsp

As Old Irish and Middle Welsh are the earliest well-attested Celtic languages, they form the basis of all work in Medieval Celtic Studies. This course focusses on their historical developments from roughly the beginning of the 1st century AD until the early Middle Ages (for Irish) or later Middle Ages (for Welsh), and the relative chronology of these developments.

In this course we will read articles and book chapters by a wide variety of leading scholars in Celtic Studies on the developments of the early Celtic languages of the British Isles. This reading will be supplemented by frequent exercises designed to cement the learning process through application of the readings to concrete problems.

In addition, students will pick a topic at the beginning of the block that will serve as their research topic for the class. During the course of the block, the readings and exercises will inform the students’ views on their research topic. At the end of the block, students will give an oral presentation on their chosen topic and write a short paper discussing the issues in a broader context.&nbsp
column2: In addition to this assessment, there will be a take-home final that will test students’ ability to apply the concepts learned during the course to a novel problem or problems.

column1: This course will help students refine their competency in data analysis as well as enhance their oral and written communicative skills.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174160,2016,Research Seminar in AMR: Late Antiquity,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['prof. dr. L.V. Rutgers'],,Course goals

This course deals with the world of Late Antiquity (third through seventh centuries CE). It seeks to familiarize students with current trends in the study of this period, with special emphasis on the transformation of the ancient world and the rise of Christianity. Special emphasis will be placed on how to work in an interdisciplinary fashion. In due course, it will allow students to develop and pursue their own research interests. &nbsp

Late Antiquity is a crucial period in European history. This was a period characterized not just by major political changes or the rise of new religious movements. There were major systemic changes as well in the way in which both state and the emerging church went about their business, with farreaching consequences regarding the social and cultural practices that stand at the very basis, to this very day, of what it means to be a European. In this course we will look at some of the overarching developments, trying to understand their importance, meaning and even relevance for today. We will also investigate why this particular field of scholarly research has seen such major developments over the last few decades. Finally we will look into new research methodologies in an effort to determine how these affect our current understanding of the period.&nbsp

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174326,2016,Research Seminar in IR/HP,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. J. Pekelder', 'dr. L. De Vita', 'dr. M.C. Beers', 'dr. R. Raben', 'prof. dr. B.A. de Graaf']",,"Course goals

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174370,2016,Research Thesis MA International Relations in Historical Perspective,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['Docent(en) van de opleiding (GW)', 'dr. J. Schenk']",,"Course goals
- Independently gaining and assessing empirical and theoretical knowledge on a specific topic at an expert level
- Independently conducting self-initiated research at an expert level and:
1) on the basis of a self-developed relevant and well-marked research question
2) to be answered through an autonomous exploration of relevant sources in combination with a legitimate method of research
- to present research results in a clear and well-structured way in writing and at an expert level &nbsp

In the Middle Ages student-craftsmen had to show their master that they were really capable of building a decent piece of furniture or forging a fine example of ironwork before they were allowed to enter the guild of their profession. Writing a final thesis is in fact a comparable exercise. Packed with the knowledge and skills you have acquired and expanded during your MA it is now time to show whether you indeed may call yourself a Master in International Relations.

As you will be writing a research thesis we expect you to offer something extra. Your 'piece of furniture or ironwork' should apart from decency also show some eloquence. In other words your research should not only be more extended, but also show a higher level of analysis including a more expanded use of sources, including primary sources. (archival material, interviews and resolutions, declarations, proceedings and policy-papers from the internet).
Note: you must have at least 25 credits for the category M (Master) before starting your thesis, obtained by completing the following courses:
GKMV16010 Ges-Modern world and states system (5 EC)
GKMV16012 Ges-Research seminar MA IR/HP (5 EC)
And two of the programme's electives:
GKMV16014 Ges-Military violence in IR (5 EC)

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174361,2016,Research Tutorial MA International Relations in Historical Perspective,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['prof. dr. B.A. de Graaf'],,Course goals
- Learning to gain and assess relevant empirical and theoretical knowledge on the tutorial's topic at an expert level
- Learning to conduct primary sources research at an expert level

- Learning to operationalise knowledge and analytical skills, a.o by writing an historiografic essay and an elaborate research proposal paying specific attention to the relevance of your research(question) compared to already existing literature
- Learning to present your research in a clear and well-structured way at an expert level, also orally, for example by explaining and defending your research proposal in class&nbsp

Common European security operations often tend to be regarded as part of a development that only started with the arrival of the UN, NATO and the EU in the second half of the 20th century. Many experts are inclined to overlook that already after the Vienna Conference in 1815 serious efforts were undertaken to establish transnational European security regimes.

In this tutorial we will compare a series of underexposed but fascinating European security missions, mechanisms and institutions from the 19th century to relevant examples from the 20th and 21st centuries, ranging from military and policing missions to international courts and conventions. We will focus on their development and ask ourselves when and how security regimes started to emerge. At the same time we will use an international and historical comparative framework to determine what has actually changed since the 19th century and whether European states learned from their experiences.

This tutorial offers you the opportunity to find your way through hardly discovered territory. The underlying idea is to sharpen your analytical skills even more in order to prepare you for writing a 20 EC research thesis at an expert plus level. If you have set your eyes on a research career in the field of International Relations, this tutorial is a must.
Note: students must have at least 25 credits for the category M (Master) before starting the Research Tutorial, obtained by completing the following courses:
GKMV16010 Ges-Modern world and states system (5 EC)
GKMV16012 Ges-Research seminar MA IR/HP (5 EC)
And two of the programme's electives:
GKMV16014 Ges-Military violence in IR (5 EC)

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/176000,2016,Research and Master Thesis Track,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,"['dr. A.M.B. Michels', 'dr. S. Beyens', 'dr. S.G. Grimmelikhuijsen', 'dr. S.L. Kuipers', 'dr. T. Schillemans', 'drs. N. van Amsterdam', 'Externe docent', 'prof. dr. J.G. van Erp', 'prof. dr. L.G. Tummers', 'prof. dr. M. Noordegraaf', 'prof. dr. M. van Bottenburg', 'prof. dr. M.J. Trappenburg', ""prof. dr. P. 't Hart""]",,"Course goals
• develop a research question (a “puzzle”) and explain the its theoretical and policy relevance
• demonstrate a thorough theoretical knowledge of the research problem through a comprehensive selection and discussion of relevant articles and books
• account for definition and operationalization of concepts, choice of research strategy, data collection and analysis
• discuss the results and confront findings with state-of-the-art as presented in the literature review
<li>present the research to the scientific forum and to different types of audiences&nbsp

The Research Master Thesis Track comprises the final project and takes part in the Spring semester of Year 2. It consists of data collection and analysis, culminating in the writing of a thesis. Students will defend their final project in a public session.

The coordinators will send possible projects to the students and discuss the various options and subjects for doing a thesis. They will agree on the first supervisor and the second supervisor. These will supervise the process. Additional meetings with the coordinators will be organized by the group of students.

The grade for your final project is based on 1) the quality of the thesis (90%) and 2) the public presentation and defense of your thesis (10%). Each student must present the final thesis to a forum of supervisors. Family, friends and fellow RESMA students may be invited. The individual supervisor decides on the grading in consultation with the second assessor (who is one of the local coordinators).

There are no standard requirements with regard to the number of pages, as the type of thesis varies with the type of research. The general rule is: quality is more important than quantity. The more concise you report your theoretical and empirical findings, conclusions – and policy recommendations - the better. As a reference point it may help to know that the thesis in the academic master programmes is required to stay within the 50-75 pages range. It may be shorter and we strongly recommend students to be concise in their writing.&nbsp

During the Research and Thesis Training (RTT), students will show their ability to individually conduct a research and write a research thesis. Students choose a topic that fits the expertise and research fields of one of the teaching staff.

Students are able to conduct a research autonomously or during an internship. Every student will have one of the teachers as a supervisor during the whole process of conducting research and writing the thesis.

The RTT runs throughout the master programme, meaning that it starts in September and ends in July. It is being taught alongside the existing master courses, making use of different interactive (face-to-face as well as virtual) teaching methods, such as individual writing assignments, seminars, group work (including peer feedback), virtual discussion boards and individual supervision.

Students will submit a provisional research proposal in October and discuss the contents with their supervisor and subgroup participants. Students cannot start the research without approval of the supervisor. Every student will have multiple meetings with their subgroup and supervisor as well as individual meetings with their supervisor. During the course there will be three seminars in which difficulties and problems with conducting research and writing a thesis will be addressed. The seminars will take place in January, March and June.

The thesis will be graded by the supervisor in cooperation with the second reader. The supervisor will be the first reader and the second reader is appointed by the thesis coordinator (dr. Brenda Oude Breuil).

K. van der Wijngaart', 'dr. K.M. Kirk', 'dr. L.H.K. Defize', 'F.M. Sterk, MA', 'M.E. de Koning', 'N. Köll, MA', 'R. Winters, LLM']",,"Course goals
After completing the course, students are able to:
explain the basic elements of scientific method
analyze texts on use of language, discourse, and rhetoric
argue their position on ethics and academic integrity
plan and structure the research and writing process

develop their own writing skills further with the help of various resources

Research in Context is a first-semester course that introduces students to research and writing in the Humanities, Social Sciences and Sciences. Students will learn about the main methodological approaches of the three academic traditions and the principles of what constitutes evidence and argumentation. They will also learn practical skills involved in setting up and carrying out research, and reporting results in written and oral form.

Each group is taught by one instructor, except for five plenary sessions for which guest speakers are invited to address the whole cohort together. In the final weeks of the course, students will present research findings to each other.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174875,2016,Research in Practice: Methods and statistics for the Social Scientist,English,University College Utrecht,,['C. Geurts, MSc', 'dr. G. de Krom', 'dr. K.T. Namesnik, PhD', 'S. van Schie, MSc']",,"Course goals
<div>After completing this course students are able to:
• design an empirical research project in the social sciences and take relevant methodological issues into account
• report research findings in a formal format resembling a peer-reviewed journal article
• conduct basic descriptive and inferential statistical procedures using the software SPSS
• (a) interpret SPSS output and (b) report the findings following the APA format
• collaborate with other students and work in a research team
• understand, apply, and explain all methodological and statistical terminology
• explain all course related methodological and statistical concepts using everyday language
<td>In this course, students are assessed 6 times :
• Written in-class quiz: this tests the knowledge and the ability to apply the methodological and statistical terminology covered in the first 5 weeks of the course (course goal 6).

• Written in-class exam: this tests the knowledge, the ability to apply, and interpret the methodological and statistical terminology and the ability to interpret SPSS output (course goals 4(a), 6, and 7).

• Research project 1: this project encompasses all aspects of an experimental research project, starting from research question and ending with a formal report (course goals 1, 2, 3, 4(a), 4(b), and 5).

• Research project 2: this project encompasses many aspects of a research project using survey data, starting from research question and ending with a presentation (course goals 1, 3, 4(a), 4(b), and 5).
• SPSS test: this tests the ability to conduct analyses using SPSS (course goal 3).

• Portfolio: this portfolio is also known as the Personal Electronic Textbook (PET). It tests the ability to rephrase and explain by means of examples all methodological and statistical concepts using everyday language (course goal 7).

Research in Practice is a project based introduction to the methodology and analysis techniques used in social science research. Students are encouraged to actively acquire all relevant information and learn from each other, through in-class group discussions and projects. The topics of this course will not follow the traditional order offered in standard textbooks, but, as the title indicates, will follow the order as needed by social science research in practice. Topics covered include research design, ethics, sampling, measurement, and various analysis techniques for associations between variables and differences between groups.

This course offers a unique combination of interactive, student-based teaching methods. No traditional textbook is used. Students are required to use various resources to search for relevant information and compile their own personal electronic textbook.
The course offers the following formats:
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/173826,2016,Research internship AI,English,Faculty of Science,,['prof. dr. M.M. Dastani', 'prof. dr. R. Iemhoff']",,"Content

A research internship is a project that should be performed by a student and under the guidance of a supervisor. The topic of the research internship should directly be relevant for artificial intelligence and agreed by the supervisor. The projects can involve the development of a software, a theoretical investigation, or an experimental research (see below for some project examples). The projects can be performed either internally in our department, or externally by other departments of our university, other universities or companies. The project should always be performed under the guidance of, and in agreement with, an internal supervisor. The students can have their own concrete project ideas or they may be interested in doing a project on a specific topic. In both cases, they can contact a supervisor with the expertise in the topic of the project in order to discuss the details of the project and if and how it can be performed as a research internship. In some cases, and in agreement with the supervisor, two students can perform a project together.
- A Power-based Spectrum for Group Responsibility
- Implementation of an agent library in Unity

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174625,2016,Research internship and master thesis,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,"['dr. G.J. Brandsma', 'dr. S.B.M. Princen', 'E. Rashkova-Gerbrands', 'J.A. den Hertog', 'L.A.J. Senden', 'mr. dr. M. van den Brink', 'mr. dr. T. van den Brink', 'mr. E.S. Lachnit', 'prof. dr. J.J. Schippers']",,"Course goals
After successfully passing the course, the student should:
Demonstrate a thorough theoretical understanding of European governance issues through a relevant and comprehensive selection of literature
Show the ability to apply this knowledge to new dynamics and developments in society that deal with aspects of European governance

Develop a research question (a ‘puzzle’) that directs the theoretical orientation to a European governance issue and accounts for a European Governance problem selection in terms of the scientific, policy and organisational relevance

Demonstrate analytical competences by presenting the results of the literature research in a consistent review that is concluded by an overview of existing gaps in scientific knowledge, hypotheses and models that guide the empirical research
Show the ability to reflect critically on the literature by elaborating a theoretically founded position in relation to the state-of-the art literature and existing theoretical perspectives
Account for definition and operationalization of concepts, choice of research strategy, data collection and analysis
Carry out data collection, analyse data and report results, taking into account methodological and ethical requirements

Analyse and discuss the characteristics and consequences of Europeanization for organizations and policy makers that deal with issues of European Governance on a local, regional, national or European level
Discuss the results and confront findings with the state-of-the-art as presented in a literature review
Translate the results into strategic policy choices and suggest concrete recommendations and policies for organizations and policy makers that deal with issues of European Governance
Present the research and its recommendations to a scientific forum and to relevant international audiences
Reflect on the progress of their individual professional repertoire that is required to enter the labour market as full academic professionals in the field of European Governance.

This course follows the key elements of the master programme’s philosophy, by (1) focussing on European governance as a phenomenon that involves multiple levels, from the local to the regional, national and European and by (2) having a interdisciplinary approach to issues of European governance, which involves the study of how organisations within this complex, multilevel governance context face and deal with issues that have a European dimension.

During the research internship, you will study an issue of European governance within an organisation that deals or has to cope with that issue. This should result in a thesis that analyses the issue at hand in a way that both conforms to standards of academic research and is valuable for the organisation in which the study was conducted.

The research for the thesis will take place in an organisation that deals with issues of European governance. You will be supervised by one supervisor from Utrecht University and one supervisor from the university at which the first year was taken (Masaryk University or the University of Konstanz). One of these supervisors will act as a daily supervisor. The other will be involved in assessing the study design and grading the thesis.

During the first semester in Utrecht, you are asked to start matching your individual interest in a research topic with a research organisation from the programme’s database or with a research organisation from your own network.

A senior member from the staff of the research organisation should supervise you during the internship period. The moment a match has been made between yourself, a research topic and a supervisor within the research organisation, you have to make arrangements on the practicalities of research internship.

Also during the first semester, you start developing a research question, literature (re)search, and write a research plan that consists both of a thorough literature overview and the design for your empirical research. The research plan should be completed by the end of january.
Most of the second semester will be dedicated to data collection and analysis, writing the thesis and presenting the research.
Further details on the planning of the research internship and the content of the master thesis will be provided at the start of the first semester in Utrecht.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171129,2016,Research practical 1,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. B. Martinovic', 'F.M. van der Werf']",,"Course goals
The aims of the course are to integrate theories with statistical methods     and     to     write     a     coherent     paper     within     a     short     time     span.

In this course, students integrate the theories of MERM1 and MERM2 with the methods and statistics of MERM3.This will be done by writing a theory-driven empirical paper that focuses on a topic discussed in MERM1 or MERM2. In the first week of the course, groups of two students choose a specific research question, and they get an introduction to the data set. Students start reading the literature and they write a theoretical introduction. In the second week they develop further their theory and hypothesis section, and make a start with their empirical analysis. In week 3, students elaborate on their empirical analysis, testing their hypotheses. Finally, in week 4, the results, conclusions and discussion of the paper have to be completed. Detailed instructions on the paper and the course proceedings will be given at the beginning of the course.</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170995,2016,Research practical 1: Time competition in families and organizations,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. A. Poortman', 'M. van der Vleuten, MSc', 'prof. dr. ir. A.G. van der Lippe']",,"Course goals

Ability to link general theory to field specific hypotheses, to analyze a complex dataset, to report on research findings in the format of a journal article. In this course students are trained to integrate theories with statistical methods in the field of stratification, employment and households.

Insights will be combined from the preceding theory course SASR1 (Sociological theory construction and model building), SASR2 (Family and social inequality), and the course SaSR3: Methods and Statistics course 1. Students will do so by writing a research paper in the format of a journal article: they choose a relevant research question, study the literature and formulate a theoretical answer, analyse data, and report on their findings. A complex dataset (Time Competition Survey) - allowing answers to a considerable number of research questions - will be made available to the students. The time competition survey is a multi-actor dataset in which information is gathered from firms, employees and their spouse (if any). During the first week, students will work on the research question the introduction of the paper, and get acquainted with the dataset. In the second week, the theory section is written, and preliminary analyses are performed. In the subsequent two weeks, the students will further analyze the data, report the results and write the conclusion. During the course, students will work in groups on their paper using the time competition survey and meet the teacher several times per week. In the fourth week students will present their (provisional) results to the other students and discuss each other&#39
column2: s work. Using the insights and remarks of the other students, they will finish their paper.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170787,2016,Research practical 2: Social network analysis,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. H.M. Weesie', 'prof. dr. A. van de Rijt, PhD']",,"Course goals
being able to define and operationalize network characteristics for ego-networks and complete networks.
formulating and testing hypotheses related to network characteristics.

using network characteristics as dependent as well as independent variable in advanced statistical techniques such as multilevel analysis and structural equation modeling. This course focuses on the integration of theories with statistical methods which are introduced separately in previous courses.

Social networks are a key concept in numerous sociological theories and     empirical     applications.     Empirically,     analyses     related     to     social     networks     are     often     quite     complex     because     of     interdependencies     between     actors,     which     violate     the     assumptions     made     in     standard     statistical     methods.     In     the     course,     different     types     of     research     problems     that     are     central     in     recent     sociological     research     and     that     require     different     statistical     approaches     will     be     discussed.     We     introduce     important     network     characteristics     and     discuss     issues     related     to     the     collection     and     reliability     of     network     data.     We     inquire     into     problems     related     to     how     social     networks     of     actors     affect     their'     behavior     and     apply     this     to     multi-level     models.     Lastly,     causality     issues     are     addressed     in     social     network     research     and     empirically     connected     to     structural     equation     modelling.     During     the     whole     course,     students     work     on     a     poster,     representing     an     own     research     problem,     arguments     and     network     analyses.     Throughout     the     course,     students     will     be     supplied     with     recent     research     articles.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171148,2016,Research project in social neuroscience,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['Docenten van de afdeling/departement(en)'],,"Course goals
In this course, a small-scale empirical study is performed under supervision of staff members.
Students write a bachelor’s thesis which tests research skills, knowledge and the use of statistics and methods employed in the field of social neuroscience.

The research project in Social Neuroscience requires students to apply their skills and knowledge that they obtained in the Minor programme in Social Neuroscience, but also to relate their skills and knowledge to their own specific field of science (e.g., Psychology, Economy or Medicine). Apart from general research skills and knowledge, students will also learn to use statistics and methodology to examine research questions that are developed in the research seminar course.
Note: This course is the fourth out of four courses in all to make up the minor Social Neuroscience.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174510,2016,Research Project Science Education and Communication,English,Faculty of Science,,['dr. A. Bakker', 'dr. ir. R.F.G. Meulenbroeks', 'dr. L.M. Doorman', 'prof. dr. W.R. van Joolingen']",,"Course goals
When having completed the project, the student is able to:
anchor his or her research project in the domain of research in science or mathematics education or communication
develop appropriate research instruments or research-based instructional materials
collect, analyze and report data in the domain of research in science or mathematics education or communication
write a coherent empirical research paper that makes a contribution to the discipline of science or mathematics education or communication
present research findings to an academic audience.

A major part of the course work in research is dedicated to students’ final research projects (30 or 45 EC). In the research project, the student will demonstrate that the academic learning aims of the master’s program have been attained. The project must satisfy the following criteria:
The research addresses a problem in Science or Mathematics Education or Communication
Expertise in science, mathematics or computer science plays a necessary role in doing the project
The project aims to answer a question by means of empirical educational research.
A project mainly aiming at developing educational material or a literature review is not acceptable.

Most of these projects will take place within the context of ongoing research at FI, or in collaboration with partner institutions such as the University Museum or SLO. Each student who will start a project from the list will be assigned to a FI research staff member (PhD) who will act as supervisor.
Alternatively, students may propose their own project ideas. In addition to the criteria stated above, the conditions for the acceptance of such proposals are:
The project is situated in a research-oriented environment
The host institution provides a qualified researcher as a supervisor
A FI staff research member (PhD) accepts the role of internal supervisor
This information has to be available to the coordinators before the formal starting date of the project
A coordinator has approved a brief proposal (two-pager) providing motivation, background information and the research question.
The paper will be written and presented in English.&nbsp

A required part of the Research Project is the accompanying student seminar that assists students in the research process: development of instruments or instructional materials, data collection, data analysis until reporting results.

This implies that drafts will be interactively discussed with peers and judged against the formal requirements. In the seminars peer feedback is used to get acquainted with other topics and types of research, to develop a critical attitude and to support each other. This is an important element in becoming a part of the FI research community. For this reason, students are also invited to assist the FI research meetings and to present their plans there.

The seminar is organized and chaired by the coordinators. During seminars on data collections and analysis, attention will be paid to the do’s and don’ts in this stage of research. Last, attention is paid to summarizing data in tables and graphical representations, style guidelines of the American Psychological Association (Sixth Edition) and time will be allocated to writing academic English. Students individually write their own paper. Students are expected to read the literature and prepare sessions with peers in which they discuss intermediary products (e.g., interview scheme, data analysis, draft paper etc). They will present their research to FI staff members near the end of the project.
Available projects can be found at the&nbsp
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/176391,2016,Research project: Twin HPS-WIS,Dutch,Faculty of Science,,[],,Course goals

<body>The thesis should demonstrate that you are able to produce new scholarly knowledge and insights according to the rules and methods current in the field of HPS, and that you can share your results with fellow researchers in a coherent way. It is based on independent research, refers to relevant litera­ture, assesses earlier work on a chosen topic and contributes to scholarly debate. Students are expected to present their findings at a colloquium for their fellow students and staff members.&nbsp
A research master thesis should consist of:
- the formulation of a problem or research question, clearly delimited thematically and (in the case of a historical thesis) in time and place
- a critical discussion of the existing scholarly literature
- a critical evaluation of the sources used
- a description and justification of the research methods used
- a discourse in which your present your own analysis on the research problem or question, presented according to the logic suggested by the formulation of the problem
- a conclusion and a consideration of the value of the research
- references in the form of footnotes
- a bibliography of the sources and literature used.
At the start, students will be provided with extensive guidelines about the research, the thesis and the procedures.</body>

M.N. Crainic', 'prof. dr. R. Fernandez', 'prof. dr. R.H. Bisseling']",,"Content
<body>At the end of a master project, the student is able to
<li>Study relevant literature and gain in-depth knowledge in a certain mathematical topic
<li>Conduct research in the field of mathematical sciences and report on it in a manner that meets customary standards of the discipline
<li>Work together on a research team (e.g., in a hierarchical team of supervisor and junior member(s), together with peers or as a trainee in a company's research team or unit)

<li>Communicate conclusions both written and orally as well as the underlying knowledge, grounds and considerations to various audiences in English (e.g. the research team, fellow researchers in the same area and master students in the same general area of mathematics)
<li>Judge and evaluate mathematical research and publications
• Enroll in a Ph.D. programme in mathematics or begin a career as a professional mathematician.

The final mark for a master project is built out of three marks which measure how well the student performed at achieving the learning goals. A detailed document with guidelines for the evaluation of the master project is published on the students website.
is able to study relevant literature and gain in-depth knowledge in a certain mathematical topic
is able to conduct research in the field of mathematical sciences and report on it in a manner that meets customary standards of the discipline
can work together on a research team (e.g., in a hierarchical team of supervisor and junior member(s), together with peers or as a trainee in a company's research team or unit)

can communicate conclusions both written and orally as well as the underlying knowledge, grounds and considerations to various audiences in English (e.g. the research team, fellow researchers in the same area and master students in the same general area of mathematics)
is able to judge and evaluate mathematical research and publications
can enroll in a Ph.D. programme in mathematics or begin a career as a professional mathematician

The average mark is the weighted average of the three marks for process, thesis and defence. The final mark is the minimum of the average mark and the mark for the thesis. Accordingly, in order for the student to pass, both the mark for the thesis and the average mark should be at least six.&nbsp

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171082,2016,Research seminar 2: Analysing, reporting and discussing your findings",English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,"['Docent nog onbekend/To be announced', 'prof. dr. ir. V.W. Buskens']",,"Course goals
The aim of the course is to guide the second-year SaSR students through designing and reporting the research for their MSc thesis.

Students are instructed and supervised in preparing the empirical part of their thesis: data collection, methods and analysis, reporting on the results. Students present and review their progress in weekly meetings. Students learn (academic skills):
• to report on their data collection, data manipulation, variable construction, and method in a clear and precise way
• to present their results, showing understanding of their findings, and reacting to criticism.
• to report on their results in a correct and clear way.
• to critically review the work of their fellow students and propose improvements.

The aim of the course is to guide the second-year MERM students through timely executing the empirical part of their MERM Thesis. Students and lecturers will weekly discuss and assist the progress of the thesis.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170887,2016,Research seminar I: Theory and hypotheses,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. T.G.E. Damen'],,Course goals
The aims of Research Seminar 1 are threefold:

First, to guide second-year SHP students through the complex tasks of coming up with a good research question and the operationalization thereof. Second, to guide students in writing up their research proposal. And third, to have the students develop those skills and engage in activities that are associated as important to being part of the academic community.

All the aims of Research Seminar 1 described above are dimensions of evaluation. The development of the research question and methodology are evaluated in the beginning of the course in the form of graded presentations. The research proposal is evaluated both in terms of conceptual and methodological clarity, as well as on writing ability. And students’ engagement to the academic community is graded by having students prepare and give 20-minute short student lectures on a topic of broad interest to the group but not on the exact same topic as their thesis research.
Grading is therefore fully connected to the learning goals of the course.</body>

The research seminars are interactive, with a strong focus on students' presentations and discussions of their project and progress. In research seminar 1, the emphasis is on instructing, supporting and supervising students in writing their research proposal, which has to be submitted to the Board of Studies. Furthermore, the theoretical part of their thesis (background, problem definition, overview of research and theories (including theoretical models), research question(s) and hypotheses), and the design and preparation of their empirical study will be of core interest. Both written products will be written in close collaboration with the supervisor and conform to the format of a high impact journal article in the domain. As a general rule, papers are expected to follow the guidelines outlined in the Publication Manual of the American Psychological Association (6th edition).

The course will take a ""learning by doing"" and ""learn from each other"" approach. Students will quickly write a first draft of their proposal, evaluate each other's proposal in small groups and continue to fine-tune their proposals until they are suitable for submission to the Board of Studies. Students will also act as each other's reviewer throughout the whole course: they learn how to give critical yet constructive comments to other students, and deal with other students' criticism. As is the case when dealing with funding agencies such as NWO, European Union and NIH, students will also learn how to make a case for why their proposals are better, more relevant or will have more impact than that of their peers.

By the end of research seminar 1, students will have (1) completed and turned in their research proposal to the board of studies (2) completed the introduction section of their thesis (including list of references), and (3) prepared the study procedures, developed materials and planned the recruitment of participants.</body>
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171206,2016,Research seminar II: Data analysis and writing up research,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. H. Marien'],,Course goals
The aim of the consecutive research seminars 1 and 2 is to guide second-year SHP students through the complex tasks of designing, conducting and reporting the empirical research for their MSc thesis.

By the end of research seminar 2, students will have (1) conducted their empirical research, (2) analyzed and reported the data, and (3) completed the thesis, including a discussion of the findings and an abstract of the study. Furthermore, students will have trained to present their work orally, also with respect to their defense in front of the Board of Studies.
The second aim of research seminar 2 is to prepare students for the activities that will be expected from them when they have become active in the scientific community.
Relationship between assessments and aims of the course

Besides offering hands-on help in interpreting and writing up data, it is the central aim of Research Seminar II to help students develop skills in presenting their research. To optimally prepare students for their active role in the scientific community, the examination will include three written assignments (a discussion paper, a review, and an symposium abstract) and their oral presentation of the thesis defense. &nbsp

The research seminars are     interactive,     with     a     strong     focus     on     students'     presentations     and     discussions     of     their     project     and     progress.     In     research     seminar     2     the     emphasis     is     on     instructing,     supporting     and     supervising     students     in     conducting     their     empirical     study,     managing,     analyzing     and     reporting     data,     and     discussing     the     findings.     Students     present     and     review     their     progress     in     weekly     meetings.     The     thesis     will     be     written     in     close     collaboration     with     the     supervisor     and     conform     to     the     format     of     a     high     impact     journal     article     in     the     domain.     As     a     general     rule,     papers     are     expected     to     follow     the     guidelines     as     outlined     in     the     Publication     Manual     of     the     American     Psychological     Association     (6th     edition).

The second aim of research seminar 2 is to prepare students for the activities that will be expected from them when they have become active in the scientific community. For that purpose, students will organize the SHP research symposium in which first year SHP students will orally present their work done during the research training SHP8. By doing this, SHP12 students will get a first experience with being a reviewer. Furthermore, they will gain experience in setting up a symposium by writing a symposium abstract based on a selection of submissions and they will also take on the role of a scientific committee by selecting the best symposium contribution.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170739,2016,Research seminar in social neuroscience,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. ir. R. Custers', 'prof. dr. B. Derks', 'prof. dr. H. Aarts', 'R. Dotsch']",,"Course goals

In this course, the link between techniques, research methods and the theoretical themes in the field of social neuroscience are analysed more in-depth. Additionally, students work on improving their programming skills in preparation of carrying out social neuroscience experiments. In the seminars students train skills necessary to develop a research proposal in smaller subgroups for the subsequent research project.

Students complete assignments during the workshops that require integrating the theoretical themes of social neuroscience on one hand and research methods and techiques on the other hand by means of writing research proposals and programming the proposed experiments.

The course will basically focus on a number of key themes, which can change each year. Within each theme, the students will be introduced to setting up and programming experimental tasks, which later can be adapted for a Social Neuroscience research project. Additionally, one of the themes will be further developed to create a research proposal in which a combination is used of one or more Social Neuroscience techniques.
Note: This course is the third out of four courses in all to make up the minor Social Neuroscience.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/176390,2016,Research Seminar Translation Studies,Dutch,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. C. Koster', 'prof. dr. A.B.M. Naaijkens']",,"Course goals

<body>De student verwerft inzicht in en kennis van de theorie van de vertaalwetenschap en van aanverwante wetenschapsgebieden en is in staat te focussen op een aantal van die deelgebieden teneinde deze nader en diepgaand te onderzoeken vanuit een vergelijkend perspectief. De cursus is gericht op het ontwikkelen van vaardigheden op het gebied van methodologie en theorie die betrekking heeft op het vak vertalen. Als onderdeel van de cursus zullen de studenten vertrouwd gemaakt worden met het proces van het indienen van artikelen voor wetenschappelijke, peer-reviewed tijdschriften.</body>

In deze cursus wordt aandacht besteed aan vertaalwetenschappelijke theorievorming vanuit verschillende aanverwante disciplines. De cursus concentreert zich op verschillende paradigma’s in de vertaalwetenschap met het doel om de studenten daar op kritische wijze mee te leren werken. Daartoe worden theoretische, historische en methodologische vragen behandeld zoals die gesteld worden vanuit de systeemtheorie, de cultuursociologie en de vergelijkende literatuurwetenschap.

De student wordt in staat geacht verschillende paradigmata in de vertaalwetenschap met elkaar te vergelijken. Zij/hoe moet de consequenties van die paradigmata voor vertaalwetenschappelijke theorievorming juist leren inschatten, dat wil zeggen de mogelijkheden en beperkingen van die paradigmata te herkennen en vervolgens op onafhankelijke wijze een bijdrage aan de theorievorming rondom vertaalwetenschap kunnen geven..

De focus ligt op sleutelwerken van Niklas Luhmann, Pierre Bourdieu, Itamar Even-Zohar en Theo Hermans. In de cursus wordt een aantal issues besproken die centraal staan in het actuele debat rond vertaling en vertaalwetenschap, zoals: wereldliteratuur en comparatisme, cultuurtransfer, transnationale poëtica’s, postkolonialisme, machtsverhoudingen, gender etc. Van studenten wordt gevraagd actief te participeren in de discussies over de genoemde issues en zich vervolgens te specialiseren in het kader van de afsluitende opdracht.</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/173376,2016,Research skills 2 (literature study and academic writing),English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,"['F.J.T. Sniekers, MSc']",,"Content

In this course, each students gathers literature on a specific topic in which he/she wants to specialize, in accordance with a member of the TKI research institute. Based on this, the student writes a literature study, in the course of which attention is given to writing skills. In principle, the literature study and research questions serve as a basis for the research proposal and research master thesis the student writes in year 2.
The course will consist of the following parts:
Overview different research cultures, including structure of argument, criteria of assessments, and nature of evidence.

column2: search strategies for finding appropriate literature.

column1: Writing skills, including instructions, exercises, and feedback.
Economic writing. How to write a review or a survey of the selected economic literature?
Student feedbacks on the literature reviews of the other students (written and presented comments)
At the end of the course the student is able to:
<div>write a well-written and well-argued review of this literature
give a clear presentation of this review.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/173377,2016,Research skills 3 (research proposal and presentation skills),English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,['T.M. van Huizen'],,"Course goals

This course pays attention to two important research skills: the writing of research proposals and the presentation of academic research. During the course, students are trained to write and to present a research proposal for external funding, in the format of a research proposal for PhD funding with NWO Research Talent. This goes beyond writing an outline of a research project. The students will participate in seminars in which (successful and unsuccessful) submitted research proposals are discussed. Furthermore, students will write a research proposal that they will present during a U.S.E. seminar. The aim of this course is to improve the students' skills in formulating and defending proposals for submission to national and international funding agencies. The deadline of the proposal will be before the NWO Research Talent deadline, so students will have the opportunity (if eligible) to submit the proposal that they have written during the course. Students can also use this proposal to apply for internal U.S.E. funding.

Furthermore, students are expected to attend regularly seminars from the external and internal U.S.E. seminar series in the first semester of the second year. By participating in these seminars, students will learn more about how to present academic research. Assessment of this part is based on three reports about the internal or external seminars: one (critical) referee report
column2: one short article for a more general audience
column3: and one report on the presentation of the study. Referee reports discuss the contributions to the field and provide several comments. Short articles should explain and discuss the implications of the research to a more general public (e.g. policy makers). One report should discuss more explicitly the form and style of the presentation: what aspects of the presentation went well and could you use in your own presentations? What can be improved? Thus, students learn to evaluate a research seminar, focusing on the content of the study, the implications of the findings and the way the study is presented.

column1: At the end of the course the student is able to:
• Write and present a research proposal for external funding (40% of the final grade)

Marien', 'dr. M. Häfner', 'dr. M.A. Adriaanse', 'E.W.M.L. de Vet', 'M.A. Strick', 'prof. dr. D.T.D. de Ridder', 'prof. dr. H. Aarts', 'prof. dr. K. van den Bos']",,"Course goals

Aim of the course is to obtain,     improve,     and     effectively     use     academic     research     skills     at     a     junior     level,     such     as     deduction     of     research     questions     and     hypotheses

Students will receive a grade for their performance during the research training. As the projects all require an idiosyncratic set of skills (e.g., theoretical skills, experimental design skills, measurement skills, data analysis skills, writing skills), their grade will be based on their progress towards acquiring the specific skill set relevant for their own project.

In this course the issues     addressed     theoretically     in     previous     courses     will     be     approached     from     a     practical     research     point     of     view.     Students     will     actively     participate     hands-on     in     ongoing     research     in     social     and/or     health     psychology,     by     working     on     research     assignments     and     assisting     in     (PhD)     research     projects.

The course starts with a plenary session introducing students to research projects they may choose to participate in. Students are then assigned to projects of their choice (depending on available places) and individual supervisors. From then on each student participates individually or in a small group in his/her research project, and receives individual training in the research group. Supervisors will provide opportunities for students to participate in multiple aspects of doing research, such as operationalization, data-collection, statistical data-processing, interpretation of findings, and academic writing. Students will participate in discussions about the progress of the research with other members of the research group.
Due to the practical character of the course a lot of informal (and individual) feedback will be given during active participation in ongoing research. Planning &
column2: evaluation     meetings     will     be     held     with     the     supervisor     at     the     start,     1/3,     2/3,     and     at     the     end     of     the     course.     In     these     meetings     student     and     supervisor     detail     the     plans     and     tasks     for     the     upcoming     period     and     evaluate     the     students     progress     with     respect     to     the     appointments     made     in     the     previous     meeting.     For     these     meetings     students     are     to     prepare     progress     reports     as     a     basis     for     their     evaluation.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170734,2016,Research training II,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. ir. R. Custers', 'Various teachers']",,"Course goals

The aim of the course is to     further     improve     and     effectively     use     academic     research     skills     that     were     addressed     in     SHP08.     In     addition,     students     will     have     the     opportunity     to     gain     experience     in     a     different     area     of     research     and     to     prepare     for     their     research     to     be     conducted     in     the     master     thesis.

Each student will actively     participate     in     ongoing     research     by     means     of     an     internship     under     supervision     of     a     supervisor     in     the     domain     of     social     and     health     psychological     research.     By     assisting     in     ongoing     (Ph.D.)     research     projects,     students     will     get     'hands-on'     experience     with     a     variety     of     steps     in     doing     research.     The     specific     activities     of     the     research     training     will     be     determined     together     with     the     daily     supervisor     of     each     student.     In     addition     to     participating     in     these     activities,     the     student     participates     as     much     as     possible     in     the     routines     of     the     research     group,     for     example     by     attending     research     meetings,     colloquia,     and     lectures.

At the end of the first year, students are introduced to a list of available research projects that they may choose to participate in. Ideally and most efficiently, this project should be linked to the master thesis project that the student will perform in the second half of this year. Students are assigned to projects of their choice (depending on available places) and individual supervisors. From September to the end of December, each student participates individually in his/her research project for 20 hours a week and receives individual training in the research group. Students will participate in discussions about the progress of the research with other members of the research group.

Due to the practical character of the course, much informal (and individual) feedback will be given during active participation in ongoing research by the supervisor, with whom planning and evaluation meetings will be held on a regular basis. In these meetings, student and supervisor detail the plans and tasks for the upcoming period and evaluate the students' progress with respect to the appointments made in the previous meeting. For these meetings, students are to prepare progress reports as a basis for their evaluation. During three 2-hour meetings at the beginning, middle and end of the internship, students will discuss their learning goals and activities that are part of the research training under the supervision of the internship coordinator. The internship report is graded by the supervisor, together with the performance during the internship.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174200,2016,Researching Arts in Society: Experimental  Ethnography Lab,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. E.A. Hubbard'],,Course goals
Thorough knowledge of ethnographic research methods in the domain of arts and society.
Ability to conduct ethnographic research using arts-based methodologies of data gathering and presentation.
Ability to collaborate on research and/or creative projects.
How might ethnographic practice be enriched by artistic practice and vice versa?&nbsp
column2: What kinds of texts could be produced from a combination of ethnographic research and artistic experimentalism? In this laboratory course, students develop experimental modes of conducting ethnographic research and producing ethnographic accounts of their field experiences. Students will engage with the theoretical perspectives on this emerging intersection while conducting field-based projects that transcend the traditional boundaries of ethnographic practice, using innovative modes of data gathering, encoding and representation – e.g., photography, digital video, audio recording, exposition, music, prose poetry, visual Arts and performance.</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174261,2016,Researching Intersectionally I,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. C.L. Quinan'],,Course goals
After completing this course, the student:
A) has formulated a research question that will form the basis of a research proposal
B) has learned to present incipient research in an oral format
C) is able to conduct academic research in the fields of Gender and/or Postcolonial Studies
D) has become acquainted with academic conventions for the research and writing of a substantive project (i.e., RMA thesis).

This research seminar has the aim of building a student body that engages in a dialogical way with the study curriculum and with individual research interests. The course offers a supportive environment in which students can reflect on potential research topics and methodological directions at a meta-discursive level. Throughout the block, focus is placed on working in small groups organized around students’ potential research projects and on presenting this early-stage research to the class. Alongside these academic goals, this seminar also serves as a productive discussion space in which students can connect with one another around academic issues or challenges.

The seminar trains students in formulating research questions and projects, in both oral and written form. This training will aid students in their future careers by learning communication and presentation skills in academic and non-academic contexts, thereby allowing them to increase the impact of their research.</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174911,2016,Resources and their Sustainable Management,English,University College Utrecht,,['dr. M.B. Eppinga', 'dr. M.J. Dekkers']",,"Course goals
After completing this course students are able to:
describe the geological and human drivers affecting natural resource availability .&nbsp
develop models that provide insight in natural ecosystem dynamics and can be used to design ecosystem conservation and restoration strategies.
explain which natural strategies exist to cope with change forced upon an environmental system
discuss how ecology and earth science relate to societal issues.

Perhaps the most important question in the field of Sustainability is how to prudently manage natural resources in their broadest sense in a time dominated by human activity, the Anthropocene. How long the impact of current human activities on planet Earth will last will largely depend on how societies choose to manage natural resources in the coming century. In this course, we identify the driving geological and anthropogenic forces determining the availability of natural resources. We will apply this knowledge when learning to develop predictive models for ecosystem dynamics, strategies to combat current societal problems arising from inappropriate resource management, and use classical economic geology obtain insight in technological solutions assisting sustainable resource management.

We develop predictive ecosystem models, starting with relatively simple interactions between species and their resources. We will also use these models to explore the consequences of recent findings in the literature that species actively modify the availability of their required resources. Also, we use modelling tools in order to understand recent observations showing that even when environmental changes are very smooth and gradual, ecosystem responses may occur very rapidly and suddenly, a phenomenon called catastrophic shifts. We will also study ore bodies, which are the result of very special geological conditions and formation processes that are rare events. In class we discuss how fossils fuels are formed and compare natural formation rates with current extraction rates. Various options how to mitigate atmospheric CO2 rise including underground CO2 storage and enhanced silicate weathering are being examined along with how rock weathering leads to mineral water with distinct and quite variable compositions. Magma composition is associated with volcanic risk. In class you will examine thin sections of a pertinent rock collection with a light microscope to discover minerals and rock properties by yourself.

Students learn from class lectures, and from scrutinizing primary literature. Web-based support is available for part of the course material. After a general course overview, the team of instructors teaches topics related to ecology and earth science in equal weight. Ecological topics include population dynamics, ecosystem engineers and catastrophic shifts in ecosystems. Earth science topics include the finiteness of resources, underground storage and stockage, hydrogeochemistry and mineral waters, and volcanic hazards.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/175834,2016,Respiration,Dutch,Faculty of Veterinary Medicine,,['dr. B. Swildens', 'dr. M.G. van Emst', 'drs. M.B.H.M. Duijvestijn']",,"Course goals

De student leert de functies en onderliggende (herstel)mechanismen van het respiratieapparaat begrijpen, zowel in rust bij het gezonde dier, als tijdens inspanning en ziekte. De student krijgt daarbij globaal inzicht in de samenhang van anatomie, biochemie, fysiologie, pathofysiologie, infectie, ziekteleer, epidemiologie en klinische verschijnselen om zo tot een therapie &amp

In het blok Respiratie wordt kennis en inzicht verkregen over de bouw, het (dis)functioneren en het herstel (reactiemechanismen) van het respiratieapparaat. De rode draad is de weg die zuurstof en kooldioxide afleggen van long naar weefsel bij het gezonde dier, inspanning en ziekte. Veel aandacht wordt besteed aan de (patho)fysiologie en de bijbehorende klinische verschijnselen in samenhang met anatomie, biochemie en ziekteleer. Tijdens de werkcollegeopdracht ervaart en bediscussieert de student de mogelijkheden om respiratoire en circulatoire parameters in rust en bij inspanning te bepalen.</body>
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/175717,2016,Respiratory system,Dutch,Faculty of Medicine,,['dr. I.E.T. van den Berg'],,Content
• To build on existing knowledge of respiratory physiology to gain insight into the pathophysiological changes at the root of respiratory conditions (the upper and lower airways and the lungs).
• To learn to diagnose and properly address common respiratory and ear, nose and throat conditions.
• To learn to differentiate between life-threatening and chronic diseases of the respiratory system.
• To recognize less common clinical pictures of the respiratory system in order to avoid therapeutic delays.

The course consists of weekly interactive work sessions Students are expected to devote a significant amount of time to independent self-study. The course handbook lists the material required to be studied prior to each meeting. Students' understanding of the material is further developed and expanded on during each session.
A pathology laboratory session corresponding to the material covered and a spirometry course are embedded into the course. The radiology education also continues parallel to the course.
Respiratory System takes place during weeks 26 through 30 of year 1 (weeks 9-13 of the year).
The course is based on the following sources:
• ClinicalRespiratoryMedicine. R.K. Albert, S.G. Spiro, J.R. Jett. Third edition. Mosby, 2004. ISBN 978-0-323-04825-5.
<li>Leerboek keel-, neus- en oorheelkunde en hoofd-hals chirurgie. Huizing &amp
Please also refer to the general textbook list.
A written/digital test takes place twice a year (one regular test and a repeat).

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/173317,2016,Rewarding Literature,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. A.L. Poletti'],,Course goals
Students acquire insight into the literary works discussed and into the process of canon formation
column2: they hone their abilities to conduct independent research, to report on this research in writing, and to present their text in academic format.</body>

column1: Over the last few decades, the Man Booker Prize has become established as a prestigious literary award for the English-speaking world. Increasingly, it has been awarded to people other than white men. For poetry, the T.S. Eliot Prize has not undergone a similar development
column2: with recent exceptions such as Derek Walcott and George Szirtes, the vast majority of winners come from the UK or Ireland, and three quarters of the winners are men. In this course, we shall address the circuit of literary prizes of various kinds, the inclusive effects they may have had, and the repercussions for canon formation. What criteria have led the judges to come to these decisions? Can we account for differences in this respect between prizes for different genres?

column1: Out of 6 assignments students need to do 3. These assignments concern the text(s) read for that week, and an analysis of the qualities that made this a winner: to what extent were these intrinsic to the text, to what extent did also ideological criteria play a role? Apart from an analysis of the primary works, this also involves research into the jury reports and other documentation. The course is concluded by a research paper focussing on an aspect of canon formation.
The course studies canon formation, which is an important &nbsp
column2: aspect of the workings of the literary marketplace. The research and writing skills taught in this course are also relevant to the work field. Guest speakers in the parallel lecture seminar.</body>

column1: After completing the course, students will be able to:
Explain how rhetoric developed in the ancient Athenian and Roman worlds and how it initially became codified
Explain who the main figures were in classical rhetoric and be able to explain how their views essentially differed
Explain the differing persuasive powers of logos, ethos and pathos
Explain the five canons of rhetoric and how they relate to each other
Explain why rhetoric has been seen as a force for both good and evil over the centuries
Apply a variety of heuristics (e.g. cubing exercises) to generate material for a paper or speech, thus overcoming inertia/writer’s block
Set up and take part in dialogic debates that will increase critical thinking
Imitate the underlying syntactic structure of any given text (style/production)
Generate doable research questions/thesis statements that fit into &nbsp
column2: appropriate research designs (including selecting an appropriate methodology)

column1: Paraphrase, recognize and produce unique examples of a designated number of style figures (schemes and tropes)
Command a broad vocabulary by means of practicing with copiousness exercises

This rhetoric module is primarily intended for humanities students with an interest in linguistics, literary studies, media studies or communication studies. It is also of interest to philosophy and (ancient) history majors. The module will also be relevant for social science students taking tracks in either: law, political sciences or (social) psychology.
Rhetoric has been, for hundreds of years, one of three core elements that make up the so called ‘trivium’
column2: the academic core of an undergraduate university education. The trivium is made up of grammar, logic and rhetoric, three skills for both learning and life that are to be encountered and acquired in this grammar-logic-rhetoric order. This introduction to the field of rhetoric (and composition) is organized in terms of the five canons of rhetoric. It follows an idealized process of writing a paper or giving a speech. This includes inventing material / ideas / arguments (and constructing sound arguments), arranging them, stylizing them, memorizing what has to be said (if a speech), and then delivering that speech (or writing that paper). In reality, and depending on the context, this process is not always as staged and linear as is suggested here. When studied with due care and attention, a good working knowledge of rhetoric will almost certainly make you a better writer, speaker and thinker.

column1: This course is a workshop-style, practice-intensive, interactive course for which a high level of qualitative participation is required (learning by doing). Students must therefore be vocal during all sessions: debating, critiquing, analysing and discussing. The following factors are also considered when determining the overall participation grade. The course will be graded based on (a) the end of term exam, which will be worth 75%, and on (b) active participation, what might be termed a combination of attendance, preparation and participation (APP), which will constitute the remaining 25% of the course grade. Students will be expected to have prepared well for the class
column2: this includes completing all assigned reading and any assigned homework exercises/assignments.

column1: This course is taught during the last five weeks of the semester. It uses the same timeslot as the UCACCMET25 group did during the first ten weeks.
Please note: this module is taught during five consecutive Wednesdays 11:00-13:45.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174089,2016,Rings and Galois theory,Dutch,Faculty of Science,,['dr. D. Schindler', 'prof. dr. C. Faber', 'prof. dr. F. Beukers']",,"Content

<div>Het eerste deel van dit college bestaat uit de theorie van de ringen. Voorbeelden van ringen zijn de gehele getallen en de veeltermen, maar er zijn nog vele anderen. Het ringbegrip omvat alle gemeenschappelijke eigenschappen van systemen waarop we een optelling en vermenigvuldiging hebben. Daarom is het een basisvak in de algebra. De volgende begrippen komen ter sprake: ringhomomorfismen, idealen, polynomen, priemidealen, maximale idealen, en veel voorbeelden.

Het tweede deel, Galoistheorie, komt voort uit klassieke problemen in de wiskunde. Bijvoorbeeld klassieke constructie problemen met passer en liniaal (trisectie van de hoek, quadratuur van de cirkel) en het probleem van de oplossing van hogere graadsvergelijkingen. Door studie van de achterliggende symmetrieën (Galoisgroepen) kunnen we vaak komen tot een oplossing van deze problemen. Belangrijk hierbij is de theorie van de lichamen (systemen met optelling, vermenigvuldiging en deling). De volgende begrippen komen ter sprake: lichaamsuitbreidingen, constructies, normaal/separabel, Galoiscorrespondentie, oplosbaarheid, eindige lichamen
Kennis en inzicht. Na afronding van de cursus kent de student:
• het begrip ring en voorbeelden van ringen
• de begrippen: ringhomomorfisme, ideaal, priemideaal en maximaal ideaal, domein, lichaam,
• verschillende toetsen voor irreducibiliteit van polynomen
Vaardigheden: Na afronding van de cursus kan de student:
• bepalen of de wortels van een polynoom algebraïsch gevonden kunnen worden
