https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/192925,2016,Social Psychology,English,University College Roosevelt,,[],,
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174802,2016,Social Psychology,English,University College Utrecht,,['dr. R.A. Renes'],,Course goals
After completing this course students are able to:
Gain an understanding of the content of social psychology: research done, theories developed
Contextualize this content in a scientific and social history of the discipline
Critically reflect on the classic studies in the field
Train the formulation of adequate social psychological research questions and methods
Carry out a social psychological research project

This course demonstrates how social psychology can illuminate our understanding of social relationships and processes. It introduces the history, theories, and methods of social psychology and encourages a critical view on social psychological research. We review classic and recent social psychology studies on social influence, interpersonal attraction, social cognition, aggression, prejudice etc.

There are two meetings each week, for 15 weeks. In the first two weeks of the course, there will be lectures and class discussions. From the 3rd week onwards, student presentations are included and work on research projects starts. All students are expected to complete the weekly readings and actively participate in the class discussions. Students read the literature and prepare it in a critical way.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174781,2016,Social Science Research Thesis -  7,5 ECTS",English,University College Utrecht,,[],,"Course goals
After completing this course, students are able to:
conduct social scientific research under the supervision of a SSC instructor
write a coherent literature review and formulate a research question
apply a suitable method to collect data and analyze the results
draw conclusions and write a coherent report.

Within the social sciences different traditions prevail. Anthropologists conduct qualitative research on the basis of fieldwork, whereas experiments or surveys involving hypothesis testing are common methods in the fields of psychology, sociology, political science and economics. In fields such as law or geography, comparative literature study in combination with case-studies may be the most appropriate method. Finally, the use of archives, combined with forms of content or discourse analysis are frequently used methods.

The student is responsible for finding a supervisor (and should start looking for the supervisor halfway the pre-research semester), and writes the thesis under his/her supervision. Students hand in a Declaration Form Bachelor's Thesis in the semester preceding the semester in which the actual research is carried out. Students have completed a research proposal of around 1000 words by the end of the pre-research semester. Deadline for the report is one week after the last day of the semester.
The Bachelor’s Thesis results in a report of 20-40 pages, consisting of: (1) an introduction to the theme
column3: (3) a research question, following from the literature review
column5: (5) a description of research results, and (6) a conclusion.&nbsp

column1: As the Bachelor’s Thesis is intended as the final stage of the academic program, students should not start a research project before finishing their second year..

All SSC majors must complete UCACCMET11 plus a level 2 methodology course of their choice. The choice should be guided by existing course prerequisites for certain level 3 courses, and the thesis topic. The UCU fellows can also help you make an informed choice.
These are the required methodologies per field. Contact the fellow about exceptions
GEO - UCACCMET22 or UCACCMET23 or UCACCMET24
LAW - UCACCMET23 + module 2D or UCACCMET24 or UCACCMET25
POL - UCACCMET22 or UCACCMET23 or UCACCMET24 or UCACCMET25
SOC - UCACCMET22 or UCACCMET23 or UCACCMET24
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174889,2016,Social Science Research Thesis - 15 ECTS,English,University College Utrecht,,[],,Course goals
In their research thesis students will learn to:
conduct social scientific research (under the supervision of a SSC instructor)
formulate a precise and relevant research question and write a coherent literature review
develop and apply a suitable method to collect data and analyze the results
draw conclusions and write a coherent scholarly essay

The research thesis involves an integrated analysis of secondary and primary research material, based on a well-formulated research question. The precise definition and requirements of the type and amount of secondary scholarly sources (most importantly the existing academic literature in the student’s field) as well as of the primary material and/or data will depend on the criteria pertinent to a particular field or track. A research thesis in political philosophy will work with different primary data than a clinical psychologist.

Students are able to choose between different thesis time formats (ie they can write their thesis over one or two semesters). All students hand in a Registration Form at mid-term in the semester preceding the semester(s) in which the actual research is carried out. Subsequently, the respective fellow assigns the student to a specific supervisor according to their area of interest. Students have to complete an initial research proposal of around 1000 words by the end of the pre-research semester.
Deadline for the report is one week after the last day of the semester.

The Research Thesis consists of two parts. Part I encompasses the development of the research question, the methodology, literature review and practical work, as well as the beginning of data collection. Part II encompasses finishing data collection, analysis of concepts and data, the integration of data and theorizing, (re)writing and conclusions.

Part I and Part II will be evaluated separately. During midterm, supervisors will provide feedback to the fellows about the progress on the theses. Subsequently, the fellows will inform the tutors about progress on the theses. The final grade for the Research Thesis is based on the combined results of Part I and II.
As the Bachelor’s Thesis is intended as the final stage of the academic program, students should not start a research project before finishing their second year..

All SSC majors must complete UCACCMET11 plus a level 2 methodology course of their choice. The choice should be guided by existing course prerequisites for certain level 3 courses, and the thesis topic. The UCU fellows can also help you make an informed choice.

These are the required methodologies per field. Contact the fellow about exceptions. E.g. if an interdepartmental major student has already taken the SCI methodology course UCACCSTA21, discuss with the fellow if it can replace the courses below.
GEO - UCACCMET22 or UCACCMET23 or UCACCMET24
LAW - UCACCMET23 + module 2D or UCACCMET24 or UCACCMET25
POL - UCACCMET22 or UCACCMET23 or UCACCMET24 or UCACCMET25
SOC - UCACCMET22 or UCACCMET23 or UCACCMET24

<li>is acquainted with the methods used in social &amp

column1: 4 colleges, 100% van het voorbereiding en nakijk werk voor de examens

This course offers comprehensive knowledge of the theoretical and experimental paradigms in the neuroscience of social and emotional behavior, based on the latest developments in these fields. The future of science as a “unity of knowledge” best reflects itself in Social and Affective Neuroscience. The primary aim is to teach students about the state-of-the-art in these multidisciplinary burgeoning fields, which combine neuroscience, psychology, biology, endocrinology, and economics, and to show how this multidisciplinary approach contributes to new knowledge concerning brain functions and social psychopathologies (e.g. social phobia, psychopathy, autism).

In this course we want to show you how the exciting field of social neuroscience looks like today, not only by giving an overview of the most important work in this field but also by letting you practice with the activities of a social neuroscientist. Therefore, this course offers both theoretical lectures and practical sessions. Each Social &amp
column2: Affective Neuroscience course day starts with a lecture and is followed by an activity or assignment in which you become a social neuroscientist yourself.

column1: Recent Scientific Review Articles on the Neuroscience of Emotion and Emotional Disorders (updated each year).

column2: CN students are strongly recommended to follow one of these courses:

column1: Social and Affective Neuroscience and/or Neurocognition of memory and attention
Optional for students in other GSLS Master’s programme:

<body>This course gives students an introduction to the research on social networks. After discussing basic concepts and theories, it is focussed on a number of topics that have been studied as a cause for the creation of social networks or as an individual consequence of having a particular type of network or relationships. We will for instance discuss whether centrality in a network equals power
column2: why we become friends with some but not with others
column3: what the function of negative relations is
column4: and whether better networks create better jobs for everyone equally. Important theoretical concepts, which explain the emergence and the consequences of social networks, will be discussed. This includes, for example the notion of the ‘strength of weak ties’, focus theory, as well as different perspectives on the theory of social capital. The course draws on examples from a diverse range of fields, from sociology to economics, and from biology to neurology.

column1: During the course, students choose a topic of their interest on which they write an essay. The paper consists of a review of the literature as well as an advice for further empirical research on the basis of this literature. During the lectures and tutorials, more information will be provided regarding the requirements related to these papers. Next to writing an essay, a midterm and an final exam will be undertaken focussing on the lectures and required readings.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170803,2016,Social innovations in policy and practice,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. M.J.M. Hoogenboom', 'M. Hopman', 'N.F. Boesveldt', 'prof. dr. G.C.M. Knijn', 'prof. dr. J.B.F. de Wit']",,"Course goals

column2: of social innovations in the social domains of work, care and welfare at the local, national and international level. The core issue of the course concerns the motivations of the participants in social innovation, the cooperation of private and public participants, and the effectivity and sustainability of social innovations. &nbsp

column1: Autonomous study of theories and concepts of social innovations, to be able to distinguish these and to analyse these critically
To gain in-depth knowledge of the character and backgrounds of social innovations, and their size and scope on basis of individually collected documentation
To gain in-depth knowledge of the ‘mechanisms that work’ of social innovations on basis of empirical studies
To study and evaluate examples of social innovations as well as of social problems occurring in the development of, the cooperation within, and the results of social innovations. &nbsp
To be able to report clearly and well documented on the results.
The exam tests: gaining in-depth knowledge of and distinguishing theories and concepts, character, backgrounds, size and scope and ‘mechnisms that work’ of social innovations.
The paper tests: the way in which student scan apply this in-depth knowledge on a self-selcetd casus and are able to report clearly and well documented.

The history of the welfare state is also a history of continuous social innovations. Innovations in the domains of social security and social services are developed and successfully implemented from top-down as well as from bottom-up. &nbsp
column2: ‘Social Innovation’ is a container concept for all those initiatives that have been developed ‘bottom-up’ by social movements and citizens’ collectivities on behalf of the development of vulnerable individuals, groups, and communities as well as on behalf of society at large (social cohesion, environment). Worldwide many examples are available
column3: food banks, bread funds, social enterprises, tutorial guidance for children in poor neighbourhoods, internet sides for mutual support, neighbourhood centres run by volunteers, sustainable power collectives, etc.&nbsp
column4: Research on social innovations is per definition interdisciplinary by combining the disciplines of socio-economics, sociology, social psychology and public administration. Social innovations appear to be a new –and necessary - niche for social cohesion as a consequence of the economic crisis, the overly bureaucratic state, decreasing public budgets, and also because of sociocultural developments (individualisation, desire for small scale activities, worries about the environment and polarisation). Citizens increasingly are involved in and committed to social innovations. Actually, this means that solidarity shifts from the national to a lower level of collectivism, from the state to the city and further down to the neighbourhood and the community. Concurrently, solidarity may also shift to the super-national level by way of global networks of public-private cooperation (fair trade). One of the implications might be that solidarity takes a different shape and is becoming part of a collectivity of ‘known people’, maybe even ‘similar people’ instead of art of a collectivity of ‘unknown and/or dissimilar people’
column5: those who are like us. Interesting scientific questions concern the motivation of the participants, mutual trust, inclusion and exclusion, and governance of public-private cooperation. Also the effectivity, efficiency, sustainability and accountancy of social innovations will be put central. Additional questions concern the relationship of social innovations to the institutions of the welfare state and its principles of redistribution and justice
column6: are social innovations the ‘last resource’ of the shrinking welfare state? These questions and the related theories will be illustrated by case-studies of social innovations in various European cities and in countries outside Europe.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171519,2016,Social Media in Context,Dutch,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. K.F. van Es'],,Course goals
Na afloop van de cursus kan de student:
- Sociale media-communicatieprocessen vanuit empirisch-analytische en mediavergelijkende
- Op tekstueel-semiotische wijze analyseren hoe deze communicatieprocessen in de sociale
- Academische kennis over sociale media en analysevaardigheden gebruiken om zich te

column2: positioneren in een academisch debat rondom sociale media</body>

column1: Sociale media maken onlosmakelijk deel uit van ons dagelijks leven, privé en professioneel. Platforms als Facebook, Twitter en YouTube zijn zo ingeburgerd dat zij steeds meer de wijze waarop wij communiceren vormgeven. Is de machtsverhouding tussen consument en producent hiermee inderdaad verschoven naar de kant van de gebruiker, zoals vaak wordt beweerd? In welke mate functioneren ze als instrumenten ten behoeve van surveillance en de exploitatie van persoonlijke data? Sociale media hebben tevens gevolgen voor gemeenschapsvorming en communicatieprocessen in de openbare ruimte.

In deze eerste cursus uit het verdiepingspakket Digitale communicatie bestuderen we het gebruik van sociale media door commerciële, maatschappelijke en politieke organisaties en leren de studenten een kritische analyse te geven van de onderliggende technologische en sociaal-culturele principes die de typische talige en audiovisuele patronen in sociale media voortbrengen.</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174557,2016,Social media in the public sphere,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,"['dr. H.A. Binnema', 'M.H. Winnubst, MA']",,"Course goals
After completing this course, the student:

column2: theoretical perspectives in the field of social media and governance from a variety of disciplines
of relationships between social media, governance,&nbsp

column1: <li>has developed skills in analyzing and evaluating recent important issues related to social media
<li>is able to apply insights from literature on contemporary questions about the role of social media in the public sphere.&nbsp

The public sphere as the place between state and society has changed considerably. Media, including mass media, internet and wireless communication networks are fundamental in the public sphere. It is through the public sphere that people enact in the public debate. Social media are regarded as the new public sphere where communication of ideas and projects emerge.Over the last years, social media such as twitter, Facebook or LinkedIn have gained prominence. They are used by different groups in society, with different purposes. In this course, we will relate social media not only to the public sphere, but also to public organizations and public professionals. &nbsp
column2: In other words, we will use three perspectives on social media: macro, meso and micro perspective.

column1: • Social media can have an impact on the way in which governments function and stimulate democratization of societies, as could be witnessed in Ukraine or in the Arab Spring. Yet, there is still a lot of discussion whether social media are really the cause of these processes and moreover, whether these are structural or temporal changes.

• Public organizations use social media for internal communication and for communication with citizens. Which (strategic) choices do they make in their use of social media, and what does this mean for their image and reputation among the public? Moreover, how do social media affect the relationship between these organizations and citizens?

• Within organizations, ranging from multinational companies to political parties, individuals use social media. How do they present themselves, for which purposes, and which is the fit with organizational purposes?

Social media will be discussed from various theoretical approaches and we will deal with topics such as collective action, identity, participation and privacy. Insights from theory will be combined with practical applications, among others through guest lectures by practitioners who are using social media in their daily work or by citizens who communicate through social media to influence the public debate.
This course requires a particularly active participation and a willingness to engage with &nbsp
column2: various forms of social media. You will work in a team on a specific project to be presented during a seminar at the end of the course. All contributions will be peer reviewed by your fellow students.

column1: After completion of this course, you will have learned to use blogs, tweets and social network sites productively and have acquired knowledge of how these forms of social media may affect governance practices.

Please note that for non-USG bachelor students the course Introduction public administration and organizational science (USG5520/USG5020) or another introductional course covering the subject of public administration is recommended.
Places will be allocated in order of subscription. If less than 10 students subscribe, the course may not be made available.&nbsp

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170977,2016,Social networks - theory and empirics,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. R. Corten', 'prof. dr. F.A. van Tubergen']",,"Course goals

The course provides an overview of the state of the art concerning contemporary research on social networks, including important research questions, theories, measurement issues, and empirical findings. The course also learns how to generalize this knowledge to social network phenomena other than those discussed in the course. Furthermore students are acquainted with some important data-sets and given a basic understanding of the research methods that are commonly used in this field.

The notion of social networks has engendered a promising research program. We will discuss core concepts of social networks, its major assumptions, as well as the research problems that it helps to solve. We will deal with, amongst others, the availability of social settings which influence the chance of meeting others
column2: the emergence and the decline of networks
column4: network effects on conflicts and occupational attainment
column5: the role of sour social capital, i.e. having enemies
column6: networks within organizations, like government agencies and the institutional conditioning the effects of networks

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171191,2016,Social risks in Europe: protection, activation and diversity",English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. M.A. Yerkes'],,"Course goals

To be able to describe social risks in Europe, including their causes and consequences, and to relate these risks to the governance of social policies and interventions, especially in the field of work, care and participation.
To be able to interpret and explain various theoretical approaches to social risks from an interdisciplinary perspective.
To be able to apply and relate these theoretical approaches to the transformation of European and national social policies.

column2: apply research skills to practical examples in social policy and social intervention research.

column1: To be able to discuss these&nbsp
column2: findings in relation to the course and construct a well-structured argument to support your findings.

column1: To be able to report these findings clearly, and in a properly organised and well-documented manner.

Through this course, you will learn how to define new social risks by looking into their background and development, learning how new social risks differ from so-called old social risks and why this matters for the governance of social policy and social interventions. Using classic as well as recent literature, we will examine how social risks develop, how they are defined and the ways in which they manifest themselves in various European countries. Examples of old social risks are unemployment, occupational disability and poverty. Protection of these social risks changed during the 1980s and 1990s following the emergence of so-called new social risks. Some new social risks are the exclusion of newcomers (women, youth, and migrants), risks centred on reconciling work and care, care shortages (for the elderly and the chronically ill) and insufficient skills/training and education. Causes of the emergence of new social risks are the same in practically all European countries: globalisation of the economy, significant labour market changes, demographic shifts and migration processes. Current topics related to the development of new social risks, such as activation policy and diversity policy will be studied and examined on the basis of both Dutch and comparative European data.

You will also learn about various theoretical explanations given to understand social risks and the policy alternatives that have been developed to manage social risks. A great deal of attention will be paid to the &lsquo
column3: , which is meant to offer an alternative for both the social protection (Keynesian) approach and neo-liberal policy approaches. On the one hand, the social investment approach attempts to provide an answer to social exclusion. On the other hand, the social investment approach tries to offer a solution to the bureaucratic regulation of social risks, the inefficiency of public services and the &lsquo
column5: citizen. The prevalence of this approach means we see a similar trend in the design of new social policies in many European welfare states: a declining role for the government, greater control from a distance, increased marketization, and the decentralisation of authority and responsibility to the local level. However, despite evidence of similar trends across European welfare states, policy transformation does not take place in the same way everywhere: in the end, the &lsquo
column7: of political systems, institutional and organisational relationships as well as socio-cultural views determine which reforms are implemented and in what way.

column1: In line with the goals of the Master&rsquo
column2: s program in Social Policy and Social Interventions, this course approaches issues from an interdisciplinary perspective at the macro level.

column1: After completing this course, students will be able to identify social risks, to articulate the various theoretical approaches to understanding social policy responses to both old and new social risks across European welfare states and to apply this knowledge to empirical examples of social policies and social interventions in both written and oral form.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170818,2016,Social cognition,Dutch,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. H. Marien', 'R. Dotsch']",,"Course goals

column7: Grondige kennis hebben van theorieën en controversies in de sociale cognitie.
Inzicht hebben in hoe robuuste kennis tot stand komt binnen de sociale cognitie.
Beschikken over vaardigheden om de methode van empirische artikelen tot in detail te begrijpen en op waarde te schatten.
Kunnen reflecteren over of interpretaties gebaseerd op een sociaal cognitieve methode gefundeerd zijn.
Beschikken over vaardigheden om replicateionderzoek uit te voeren en te interpreteren.

column1: Het tentamen is met name ontworpen om vast te stellen in hoeverre de student kennis heeft opgedaan op het gebied van de sociale cognitie (leerdoel 1 en 2). De opdrachten in de werkgroepen zijn ontworpen om vast te stellen in hoeverre de student voldoet aan leerdoelen 3, 4, en 5.
In dit vak maakt de student kennis met belangrijke theorieën en empirisch onderzoek op het gebied van de cognitieve sociale psychologie.
Vragen die aan de orde komen zijn onder andere:
Hoe evalueren mensen hun sociale omgeving?
Hoe wordt conceptuele kennis opgeslagen en gebruikt?
Hoe komen oordelen en beslissingen tot stand?
Hoe en wanneer controleren mensen hun impulsen?

De cursus heeft een sterke methodologische component, waarbij het nauwkeurig lezen van methode secties van empirische artikelen, het inschatten van de robuustheid van onderzoek en het repliceren (herhalen) van bestaand onderzoek een centrale rol heeft.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170764,2016,Social and emotional development,Dutch,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. A.E. Aleva', 'dr. S.C.E. Thomaes', 'prof. dr. J.J.S. Dubas']",,"Course goals
Verdieping van kennis en inzicht met betrekking tot&nbsp
column2: recente ontwikkelingen aangaande onderwerpen van de sociale en emotionele ontwikkeling van kinderen.

column1: De normale sociale en emotionele ontwikkeling van kinderen herkennen en beschrijven
De samenhang tussen diverse ontwikkelingen op sociaal en emotioneel gebied herkennen en beschrijven
Kritisch reflecteren op theorie en onderzoek aangaande de sociale en emotionele ontwikkeling, zowel schriftelijk als mondeling.

Verdiepende kennis in de normale sociale en emotionele ontwikkeling van kinderen en de samenhang tussen diverse ontwikkelingen op sociaal en emotioneel gebied wordt getoetst in de deeltoetsen. Inzicht in recente ontwikkelingen in het veld en het kritisch reflecteren op theorie en onderzoek uit het gebied wordt getoetst aan de hand van de paper en het referaat.
In deze cursus wordt nader ingegaan op onderwerpen binnen de sociale en emotionele ontwikkeling die deels aan de orde zijn geweest in de cursus &lsquo
column3: . Onderwerpen als persoonlijkheidsontwikkeling, emotionele ontwikkeling, socialisatie binnen en buiten het gezin, zelfbeleving, sociale competentie, morele ontwikkeling, altru&iuml
column4: sme, agressie en pesten komen aan de orde. Van deze onderwerpen wordt de ontwikkeling in de (vroege) kindertijd en adolescentie (0-18 jaar) belicht. Het accent ligt op de normale ontwikkeling, maar relaties met deviante ontwikkeling worden gelegd waar mogelijk. In de werkgroepen wordt van studenten een actieve houding en kritische reflectie op theorie en onderzoek gevraagd. Door middel van een referaat wordt geoefend in mondeling rapporteren en door middel van een paper in schriftelijk rapporteren.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170945,2016,Social innovations in policy and practice,Dutch, English",Faculty of Social Sciences,,"['dr. M.J.M. Hoogenboom', 'M. Hopman', 'N.F. Boesveldt', 'prof. dr. G.C.M. Knijn', 'prof. dr. J.B.F. de Wit']",,"Course goals

Inzicht vergroten in sociale innovaties op lokaal, nationaal of internationaal niveau op de maatschappelijke domeinen arbeid, zorg en welzijn. Centraal staat in deze cursus de motivatie van deelnemers aan sociale innovatie, de samenwerking tussen private en publieke deelnemers aan sociale innovatie, en de effectiviteit en duurzaamheid van sociale innovaties.
<li>Zelfstandig wetenschappelijke benaderingen en concepten van sociale innovaties te bestuderen, deze van elkaar te leren onderscheiden en deze kritisch te analyseren
• Inzicht te verkrijgen in de aard en achtergronden van sociale innovaties en in de omvang en reikwijdte ervan op basis van zelfstandig verzamelde documentatie.
<li>Inzicht te verkrijgen in de werkzame mechanismes van sociale innovaties op basis van empirische studies
• Voorbeelden te bestuderen en beoordelen van sociale innovaties en de vraagstukken die zich voordoen bij de ontwikkeling van, de samenwerking in en de resultaten van sociale innovaties.
• Over bevindingen helder en goed gedocumenteerd rapporteren

Het tentamen toetst de leerdoelen: inzicht in en onderscheiden van wetenschappelijk benaderingen en concepten, en de aard, achtergronden, omvang, reikwijdte en werkzame mechanismen van sociale innovaties.
Het paper toetst de wijze waarop studenten deze inzichten kunnen toepassen op een zelfgekozen casus en daarover helder en goed gedocumenteerd kunnen rapporteren.</body>

<body>De geschiedenis van de verzorgingsstaat is tegelijkertijd een geschiedenis van continue sociale innovaties. Zowel op het terrein van dienstverlening als op dat van de sociale zekerheid zijn innovaties niet alleen van bovenaf maar vaak ook van onderop geïnitieerd en succesvol geïmplementeerd. ‘Sociale Innovatie’ is een verzamelterm voor al die initiatieven die van onderop ontstaan en door sociale bewegingen of collectieven van burgers worden gedragen ten behoeve van de ontwikkeling van kwetsbare individuen, groepen of buurten, of in het algemeen belang (sociale samenhang, milieu). Wereldwijd zijn er talloze voorbeelden
column2: voedselbanken, broodfondsen, huiswerkbegeleiding voor kinderen in achterstandswijken, internetsides voor wederzijdse hulp, door vrijwilligers gerunde buurtcentra, energiecollectieven,&nbsp

column1: Het onderzoek naar sociale innovaties is per definitie interdisciplinair en combineert sociaaleconomische, sociologische, sociaalpsychologische en beleidswetenschappelijke benaderingen. Als gevolg van de economische crisis, de verbureaucratiseerde overheid, krimpende publieke middelen maar ook als gevolg van sociaal-culturele ontwikkelingen (individualisering, behoefte aan kleinschaligheid, zorgen om milieu en tweedeling) zijn zulke innovaties van onderop meer noodzakelijk en nemen burgers weer volop initiatieven. Feitelijk betekent het dat solidariteit verschuift naar een lager en kleinschaliger niveau, van de staat naar de stad en verder door naar de wijk of de buurt maar ook gedragen kan worden door wereldwijde netwerken van publiek-private samenwerking (fair trade). Het betekent mogelijk ook dat de solidariteit verschuift van het collectief van ‘onbekenden’ naar de gemeenschap van ‘bekenden’, mogelijk zelfs ‘gelijkgezinden’
column2: degenen die zijn zoals wij. Wetenschappelijke vragen die daarbij opkomen betreffen de motivatie van de deelnemers, onderling vertrouwen, insluiting en uitsluiting, governance van de publiek-private samenwerking maar ook hoe effectief, efficiënt en duurzaam zijn sociale innovaties, en hoe verhouden ze zich tot veranderingen in de institutionele setting en de verdelende rechtvaardigheid van de verzorgingsstaat
column3: zijn sociale innovaties de stoplap van de krimpende overheid? Deze vragen en de gebruikte theoretische benaderingen worden geïllustreerd met en besproken aan de hand van casestudies van al dan niet geslaagde vormen van sociale innovatie die verricht zijn in Europese steden en in landen buiten Europa.</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171187,2016,Social problems,Dutch,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['N.H.M. van Gerwen', 'prof. dr. ir. A.G. van der Lippe']",,"Course goals
Het verkrijgen van kennis en inzicht in een drietal sociale problemen in Nederland, wat betreft: de huidige stand van zaken, &nbsp
column4: en de mogelijkheden om via beleid invloed uit te oefenen

column1: Zelfstandig informatie over sociale problemen kunnen verzamelen, verwerken en presenteren&nbsp
Op basis van cijfers en ander wetenschappelijk materiaal leren reflecteren op de standpunten van politieke partijen en opiniemakers.
Verkenning van samenlevingsproblemen in Nederland als bron voor sociologische vragen.

Met welke sociale problemen wordt Nederland momenteel geconfronteerd en hoe gaan we met deze problemen om? Sociale problemen komen vaak voort uit ongelijke verdelingen, niet elke ongelijke verdeling geeft echter aanleiding tot een sociaal probleem. Een sociaal probleem komt soms ook voort uit conflicten en belangentegenstellingen die tussen sociale groepen bestaan: aan sociale problemen herkent men de structuur van de samenleving.

Zo komen er in deze cursus diverse sociale problemen aan de orde, zoals sociale (on)zekerheid, arbeid en werkloosheid, zorg, onderwijs en multiculturaliteit en jeugdcriminaliteit, die op een vergelijkbare wijze zullen worden benaderd. Om de doelen te bereiken wordt&nbsp
column3: de werkvormen: hoorcolleges, werkgroep, practica en projectgroepen.

column1: In de hoorcolleges wordt de achtergrond van de diverse sociale problemen behandeld: de omvang en de aard van het probleem, de bestaande verklaringen, en voorkomende oplossingen in beleid.
In werkgroepen ligt de nadruk op het beschouwen van casussen met betrekking tot een bepaald maatschappelijk probleem. Studenten&nbsp
column2: bestuderen en analyseren gezamenlijk de casus, waarna zij zich verder in het probleem inwerken m.b.v. literatuur, media, internet, deskundigen, observatie, etc. Daarbij leert de student de weg naar de verschillende bronnen van wetenschappelijk materiaal te vinden en de (elektronische) zoeksystemen te hanteren (bibliotheekopdracht).In de &nbsp
column3: projectgroepen zullen studenten onder begeleiding in groepjes een ingezonden brief en opiniebijdrage leren schrijven over een maatschappelijk probleem. Zij dienen deze bijdragen in bij een krant of weekblad. Daarnaast wordt aandacht besteed aan wetenschappelijke integriteit.

column1: Deze cursus draagt bij aan het behalen van de volgende eindtermen:
<li>De belangrijkste maatschappelijke problemen in de hedendaagse Nederlandse samenleving in internationaal vergelijkend en historisch perspectief
column2: alsmede het verschil met sociologische vragen.

column1: <li>Maatschappelijke problemen analyseren en deze ‘omzetten‘ in sociologische problemen
column2: en deze deelproblemen ordenen onder overkoepelende sociologische problemen.

column1: <li>Oordelen over de urgentie van maatschappelijk probleem
column2: vaststellen of (o.a. in relatie met het maatschappelijk probleem) een sociologisch probleem goed is gesteld.

column1: • Beschikken over algemene professionele en academische vaardigheden met betrekking tot de Nederlandse en de Engelse taal
<li>Kunnen mondeling presenteren, discussiëren, helder formuleren en adequaat rapporteren
• Hebben het vermogen zelfstandig te werken en zelfstandig hun werk te plannen.
<li>Kunnen actief deelnemen aan groepsdiscussies, constructief commentaar geven en in kleine groepen samen werken
<li>Relevante informatie opzoeken en selecteren in de bibliotheek en op internet
• Kennis hebben van de inhoud van de gedragscode van de Nederlandse Sociologen Vereniging.
• Kunnen reflecteren op ethische aspecten van sociologisch onderzoek en van hun handelen.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170865,2016,Social psychology,Dutch,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. ir. R. Custers', 'dr. J.H.A. Hogendoorn', 'M. de Vries', 'M.A. Strick', 'prof. dr. K. van den Bos']",,"Course goals
Let op: Deze cursus telt mee bij de totstandkoming van het Bindend Studieadvies voor eerstejaars bachelorstudenten. (Informatie en vragen over de cursus (majorverplicht@uu.nl)
Deze cursus biedt een verdieping in de sociale psychologie en een kennismaking met de mogelijke toepassingen van de sociale psychologie. Een student dient na de afronding van deze cursus:
uit te kunnen leggen hoe in specifieke sociaal-psychologische theorieën gedrag wordt geanalyseerd en hoe in de sociale psychologie gedrag empirisch wordt onderzocht
uit te kunnen leggen hoe de sociale psychologie wordt toegepast, met name bij interventies in de maatschappij en in organisaties
deze kennis te hebben toegepast in een aantal opdrachten
aan te kunnen geven hoe cultuur en sociaal gedrag samenhangen
de relaties van de sociale psychologie met andere onderdelen van de psychologie aan te kunnen geven
de beroepsprofielen op het gebied van de sociale psychologie te kunnen benoemen
inzicht te hebben verkregen in de wetenschapsfilosofie van de sociale psychologie.

een onderzoeksvraag met bijbehorende hypothesen te kunnen formuleren en deze probleemstelling, alsmede de methode van onderzoek en de resultaten te kunnen plaatsen in de kennis en literatuur van de sociale psychologie.

een begrijpelijk onderzoeksverslag te kunnen schrijven, dat wil zeggen de opzet van een onderzoek zo kunnen beschrijven dat eenieder dit onderzoek op precies dezelfde wijze kan herhalen en de resultaten te kunnen interpreteren en dusdanig presenteren dat deze voor iedereen begrijpelijk en overzichtelijk zijn.
de eerder opgedane kennis en vaardigheden uit MTS1 te hebben toegepast, en vaardigheid in het werken met computerprogramma's zoals SPSS en Excel te hebben uitgebreid.

Binnen deze cursus wordt op twee manieren getoetst. Allereerst dient er een onderzoeksverslag te worden geschreven waarvoor de student deelneemt aan verschillende onderzoekspractica waarin hij/zij leert hoe sociaal psychologisch onderzoek tot stand komt. Door middel van het schrijven van dit onderzoeksverslag leert de student hoe verslaglegging van dergelijke sociaal psychologische onderzoeken in elkaar steekt, namelijk het opstellen van hypothesen, het plaatsen van dit onderzoek binnen het kader van de sociale psychologie, het helder verwoorden van het onderzoek zodat eenieder het op gelijke wijze kan herhalen, het interpreteren van data en het kritisch bekijken van de uitkomsten. Na het schrijven van dit onderzoeksverslag is de student op de hoogte van verslaglegging van sociaal psychologische onderzoeken en heeft hij/zij kennis opgedaan over onderzoek doen binnen de sociale psychologie.

Naast het schrijven van een onderzoeksverslag wordt deze cursus afgesloten met een meerkeuzetoets. In deze toets worden meerkeuzevragen gesteld over de toepassing, kennis en literatuur van de sociale psychologie. Er zal een verscheidenheid aan vragen voorkomen naar onder andere enkele sociaal-psychologische theorieën, de toepassing van sociale psychologie in de maatschappij, de relatie tussen sociaal gedrag en cultuur en de plaats van sociale psychologie binnen de psychologie, Na het behalen van de toets heeft de student weet van alle aspecten die behoren tot de sociale psychologie en is hij/zij in staat deze kennis toe te passen in sociaal psychologische vraagstukken
De sociale psychologie bestudeert de mens als een&nbsp
column3: wezen wiens gedrag wordt gevormd en gereguleerd door andere individuen en groepen. Als zodanig onderzoekt de sociale psychologie de cognitieve, emotionele, motivationele en gedragsmatige effecten als reactie op de (directe en denkbeeldige) aanwezige sociale omgeving. Kortom, ons denken, gevoel en doen en laten wordt sterk beïnvloed door de mensen om ons heen. In de cursus&nbsp
column5: wordt hiertoe ingegaan op hoe we informatie over onszelf en over andere personen verwerken, hoe we deze informatie omzetten in gedragd en welke inloed gevoelens daarbij spelen. De voornaamste theorieen, klassieke onderzoekingen en recente inzichten op dit gebied worden hiertoe besproken. Dit gebeurt aan de hand van drie centrale domeinen. Het eerste domein betreft het waarnemen en begrijpen van onszelf en anderen. Het tweede domein betreft sociale beïnvloeding, waarbij met name de wijze waarop andere mensen (als individuen of als groep) onze meningen en gedrag beïnvloeden en veranderen centraal staat. Het derde domein heeft betrekking op sociale interactie en relaties.

column1: Voorts wordt kort aandacht besteed aan de toepassing van de kennis en methoden binnen de sociale psychologie. Dit gebeurt binnen het onderzoekspracticum.
Een belangrijk onderdeel van de cursussen: Ontwikkelingspsychologie, sociale psychologie, psychologie als wetenschap, persoonlijkheid &amp
column2: gezondheid vormt het onderdeel vaardigheden in wetenschappelijk denken en onderzoek. Hoewel bij elk vak een andere set van vaardigheden is ondergebracht, zijn deze natuurlijk voor elk vak binnen de psychologie van belang. Binnen de cursus psychologie als wetenschap en de cursus Sociale Psychologie ligt daarbij de nadruk op praktische experimenteervaardigheden en het schrijven van een wetenschappelijk verslag in de vorm van het onderzoekspracticum. Het gaat in het onderzoekspracticum naast&nbsp
column3: de inhoud, ook om de (schrijf)vaardigheden, en het aanleren van 'wetenschappelijke vaardigheden' bij het doen van onderzoek.

column1: De student neemt in het onderzoekspracticum twee verschillende rollen op zich: Die van onderzoeksdeelnemer en die van onderzoeker, waardoor eventuele methodologische obstakels duidelijk zichtbaar kunnen worden. Tijdens het practicum zullen verschillende soorten onderzoek de revue passeren. Een telkens terugkomend thema zal zijn: Meet het instrument daadwerkelijk wat de onderzoeker wil meten, en hoe kan de onderzoeker daar zeker van zijn?

Bij het onderzoekspracticum Sociale Psychologie behoren aan elkaar gerelateerde onderzoeken, waarover één onderzoeksverslag dient te worden geschreven. Daarnaast zullen er een aantal korte opdrachten worden uitgevoerd. Als leidraad voor het schrijven zullen onder andere de normen van de American Psychological Association (APA) worden gehanteerd.
Gebruik van data-analyse pakketten zoals Excel en SPSS
Duidelijk presenteren van resultaten en bevindingen
Systematisch zoeken en interpreteren van wetenschappelijke publicaties
Begrijpen en toepassen van ethische aspecten van het onderzoek
Kritisch analyseren en beoordelen van eigen onderzoek en bevindingen
Het kunnen plaatsen van argumenten in een wetenschapsfilosofische context.

In staat zijn om sociale risico’s in Europa te omschrijven, inclusief de oorzaken en consequenties daarvan, en deze risico’s kunnen relateren aan de governance van sociaal beleid en interventies, in het bijzonder op het terrein van arbeid, zorg en participatie.
In staat zijn om verschillende theoretische benaderingen van sociale risico’s te interpreteren en te verklaren vanuit een interdisciplinair perspectief.

In staat zijn onderzoeksvaardigheden toe te passen op praktische voorbeelden van onderzoek naar sociaalbeleid en interventies.

het Nederlandse politieke en bestuurlijke systeem globaal beschrijven en vergelijken.
het verloop van een bestaand beleidsproces reconstrueren en de gebeurtenissen verklaren aan de hand van sociaal-wetenschappelijke theorie&euml

helder rapporteren en op academisch niveau beargumenteren en analyseren.
In deze cursus leren studenten beleidsprocessen te begrijpen en analyseren. Veel studenten in de sociale wetenschappen zullen in hun latere beroepspraktijk &nbsp
column2: direct of indirect met beleid en politiek in aanraking komen. &nbsp
column3: Deze cursus zet een eerste stap in het ontwikkelen van kennis en vaardigheden op dit terrein We starten met de introductie van de belangrijke actoren en instituties in de Nederlandse en Internationale bestuurlijke en politieke context (“De schaakstukken”). Vervolgens gaan we stapsgewijs de fasen van het beleidsproces langs (“Het schaakspel”): er wordt besproken waarom sommige onderwerpen de publieke agenda bereiken en anderen niet, hoe besluitvorming verloopt, waarom sommige oplossingen voor maatschappelijke problemen worden opgenomen in beleid en anderen niet, en wat succes- en faalfactoren in de uitvoering zijn. Door de hele cursus heen leren studenten hoe zij overheidsbeleid kunnen begrijpen en analyseren met behulp van theorieën uit de sociologie, politicologie en bestuurskunde.Voor studenten is dit een interessante cursus omdat zij leren om de diepere (en spannende) achtergrond te doorgronden van belangrijke, actuele maatschappelijke discussies. Hierdoor leren zij om discussies zuiverder te voeren en argumenten wetenschappelijk te onderbouwen.&nbsp

column1: De behandelde stof in de hoorcolleges wordt toegepast in de werkgroepen. Dit gebeurt aan de hand van een aantal actuele cases ontleend aan krantenartikelen, onderzoeksrapporten en beleidsteksten.

Studenten worden op verschillende manieren getoetst. Naast het maken van een tentamen, schrijven studenten een paper waarin ze een bestaand beleidsproces analyseren met behulp van wetenschappelijke theorieën en maken ze een opdracht aan de hand van de ‘documentary game’ Fort McMoney.
Deze cursus vormt een goede voorbereiding op de cursus Policy and Evaluation Research (BA 2, code 201600411).&nbsp

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/172750,2016,Societal Challenges & Innovation Theory,English,Faculty of Geosciences,,['dr. F.R. van Rijnsoever', 'prof. dr. E.H.M. Moors', 'prof. dr. M.P. Hekkert']",,"Course goals
<body>After completion of the course the student:
<li>has advanced knowledge and understanding of theories of technical change and innovation in the context of societal challenges (IS degree qualification 1)
<li>has the ability to apply knowledge, and problem-solving abilities related to societal challenges and innovation&nbsp

<li>has insight into the complex interactions between science, innovative technology and society and is able to reflect critically upon the roles of science and technology in organizations and society

<li>has professional and academic skills (Concise writing, Valuing literature, Argumentation and reasoning, Reflection on science and society, Selection of theories and presentation skills), in particular in relation to societal challenges and innovation
<li>is able to apply knowledge to concrete societal problems (IS degree qualification 6)

• is able to communicate conclusions, as well as the knowledge, reasons and considerations underlying these conclusions, to an audience of specialists and non-specialists alike. (IS degree qualification 7).

<body>The analysis of innovation processes is much more powerful when using theories of technical change and innovation. Theories of technical change and innovation can be a powerful tool to understand and help solve some of the grand challenges that&nbsp
column2: our society faces, like climate change or the development of new medication. This course teaches students to apply theories in a sensible, logical and practical way.

column1: During this course we will reflect on what it means to use and apply theories in a research and policy context. We will do so by first by &nbsp
column2: reflecting on what theories are and how solid theoretical models are built . Next, we reviewing the main strands of theorizing in innovation studies and their role in innovation and transition policy. We then turn to various key topics in innovation research that are reflected in policy debates.

column1: After having reflected on the usefulness of applying theories in a research setting students practice with choosing and applying theories to a practical research question in the area of sustainable innovation or life sciences. Different theories that&nbsp
column2: build on the content of Technology Related Venturing and Innovation Systems and Processes are central in this. After thoroughly reflecting on the usefulness, the applicability, the basic assumptions and the effects on outcomes of these theories, students need to use these theories to solve a concrete research problem.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/176618,2016,Socio-ecology,Dutch,Faculty of Science,,['dr. A.M. Schel', 'dr. M.J.H.M. Duchateau', 'prof. dr. E.H.M. Sterck']",,"Course goals
Na afloop van het theoretische deel van deze cursus kan je:

column2: Behavioural Ecology in de master Environmental Biologie. Deze cursus is verplicht voor het masterprogramma Behavioural Ecology.

column1: De cursus is een verdere verdieping van de niveau 2 cursussen Gedragsbiologie en Cognitie en Gedrag.

Het thema van de cursus is sociaal gedrag. Organismen kunnen leven in groepsformaties die varieren van eenvoudige aggregaties tot complexe geïndividualiseerde gemeenschappen met daaraan gerelateerd verschillende sociale strategieën. Er wordt ingegaan op de ultimate kant van socialiteit met de verschillende sociale strategieën en evolutionaire theorieën erover zoals game theoretische modellen
column5: altruïsme en eusocialiteit. Aan bod komen sociale mechanismen zoals coördinatie van gedrag, sex allocation en verspreiding, prosocialiteit, empathy en sociale intelligentie, conflict en conflicthantering (dominantie
column7: zelforganisatie. De proximate kant van gedrag, de fysiologie, zal besproken worden.

column1: Tijdens het praktische deel van de cursus wordt een ministage gedaan met observationeel onderzoek aan Java-apen, waarbij de observaties plaats vinden bij BPRC te Rijswijk. De onderzoekscyclus wordt doorlopen met vraagstelling, verzameling van observationele data, data analyse aan de hand van Matman en sociale netwerkanalyses , statistische toetsing, schriftelijke verslaglegging en poster presentatie met een elevator pitch.
Interactieve hoorcolleges, werkcolleges, onderzoek, verslag, peer-review, poster, elevator pitch

Het eindcijfer kan alleen berekend worden als alle deelcijfers voldoende zijn.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/175168,2016,Socio-economic Processes,English,Faculty of Geosciences,,['J.C.M. Roodenrijs, MSc', 'W.B. Vermaat, MSc', 'W.I. van Enst, MSc']",,"Course goals
<body>After completion of the course, the student is able to:
<li>recognize, explain and reflect upon the fundamental ideas from both sociology as well as economic theory
<li>recognize the core message of an article, relate this to core messages from other articles and critically reflect upon it
<li>analyze a sustainability problem from an economic or social theoretical perspective and explain this to others
• write an essay in which a sustainability issue is related to an economic or social theory.

In this course you will reflect upon social and economic theories and you will relate them to current environmental events. This will help you understand the societal and economic causes or drivers for sustainability problems and the impact they have on both a local and global scale.

This course will also address that a different mind-set leads to different solutions for sustainability problems. It forces you to think critically about historical and present lines of thought within social- and economic science. This course encourages you to express your opinion on social and economic theories, and aims to make you able to argument your viewpoint.

The set-up of the course is as follows: first, lectures provide you with the fundamental ideas from both sociology and economic theory. Each lecture is accompanied by some articles about the theory being discussed, which you will read in preparation for the tutorials. An exam takes place in the seventh week, after which you will write an essay.
Under reservation: this course includes an Honours component.
• Writing a paper on the field of study (research paper, advisory report, review, essay, newspaper article, webpage)
• Oral presentation, appropriate to a given audience
• Placing knowledge and understanding in a wider scientific, societal and ethical context
• A scientific attitude in describing, explaining and predicting events (logical reasoning, arguing, analyzing and critical thinking)
• A professional attitude when carrying out work (collaboration)
This course is the entry requirement for: to be decided.</body>

Studenten hebben kennis en inzicht van basisbegrippen, theorie&euml
column2: n, inzichten en kernfiguren uit de sociolingu&iuml
column3: stiek en inzicht in de relatie tussen taal en maatschappij. Ze kunnen sociolingu&iuml
column4: stische problemen identificeren en analyseren en op (basisniveau) &nbsp
column5: onderzoeken. Daarbij kunnen ze op heldere wijze in geschreven en gesproken vorm bijdragen aan huidige debatten over talige kwesties in het publieke domein.&nbsp

column1: <div>In deze cursus staat de relatie tussen taal en maatschappij centraal. We besteden daarbij speciale aandacht aan het Nederlandse taalgebied. We buigen ons over de vraag hoe en waarom taalvariatie ontstaat, en welke sociale, individuele en linguïstische factoren daarin een rol spelen. We maken kennis met tal van onderwerpen zoals standaardtaal, accent en dialect, jongerentaal, etnolecten, verschillen tussen mannen en vrouwen, de relatie tussen taalvariatie en taalverandering, stijlverschillen binnen een taal, taalseksisme en de sociale waardering van taalverschillen. Daarnaast komen ook onderwerpen zoals taalplanning, meertaligheid, codeswitching, de positie en het onderwijs van minderheidstalen, taalverlies en taalverschuiving bij immigranten in Nederland en bij Nederlanders in het buitenland aan bod.&nbsp

In deze cursus is Luistertaal mogelijk. Deze cursus wordt aangeboden in het Nederlands. De cursus staat ook open voor studenten die deze taal vooral receptief beheersen (als luistertaal). Deze studenten kunnen desgewenst in het Engels deelnemen, en ook toetsonderdelen in die taal afleggen. Als je van luistertaal gebruik wilt maken, neem dan direct na inschrijving contact op met de docent. Let op: als je van luistertaal gebruik maakt, dan wordt deze cursus opgenomen in de profileringsruimte van je opleiding. De cursus kan dan niet gelden als taalspecifieke cursus binnen het major of minor onderdeel van je opleiding.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/172386,2016,Sociological Theories: Models for the Analysis of Social Interaction,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,['T. Spiegel'],,"Content
Please note the prerequisites for this course, you are expected to have knowledge of certain courses.

This is an intermediate undergraduate level course on theory formation and model building in sociology. Thus the course focuses on the `Theory', in the `Problems-Theory-Empirical Research-Policy Implications'-sequence that characterises the various steps in analytical social science. The focus is on the common 'logic' underlying different, sometimes competing but also often complementary, sociological approaches. We discuss the core steps involved in theory formation and model building: the formulation of problems (societal problems as well as sociological problems), (re)construction of theories, derivation of testable hypotheses from general theories, and generating policy recommendations using sociological theories as well as results of empirical research. A focus on carefully designed arguments is a characteristic feature of the course: What assumptions do we need in order to derive certain implications? What implications follow from a certain set of assumptions? This includes making assumptions explicit which often remain implicit in theoretical reasoning. Another feature of the course is that we carefully reconstruct the links between propositions on the micro-level of individual behaviour and propositions on the macro-level of social phenomena and processes. For this purpose, we introduce students to theoretical tools such as game theory and agent-based modeling. The course proceeds from examples of sociological analyses, each related to one of the main themes of sociology as a discipline: problems of order and cooperation (sometimes referred to as the problem of cohesion), problems of social inequality, and problems of social change.
NB: the course is taught in English.
At the end of the course, the student is able to:
<li>Use sociological theories for generating tentative answers to explanatory problems
<li>Provide reconstructions of theoretical sketches in the form of explanatory theories and models
<li>Use explanatory theories and results of empirical research for developing policy recommendations
Lectures, instructional lectures, coachgroups, tutorials, computer labs.
In order to be eligible for a retake exam, the student has to:

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171047,2016,Sociological theory construction and model building,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['prof. dr. ir. V.W. Buskens', 'prof. dr. W. Raub']",,"Course goals
The course familiarizes the student with:
(a) Basic features of problem-driven and systematic (deductive) theory construction, model building, and explanation in social science
(b) Micro-models and game-theory models of behavior
(c) Systematic reconstructions of social science theory and applications of social science theory in various fields of sociology.

Basic features of problem-driven and systematic (deductive) theory construction, model building, and explanation in social science are illustrated using, among other things, macro- and micro-features of explanatory models as well as macro-micro-macro transitions. Basic micro-models include an introduction to principles of rational choice theory, microeconomics, game theory, behavioral models and applications of&nbsp
column2: theoretical tools in sociology (these models are explicitly or implicitly used in many fields of sociology, including fields such as the interface of stratification and households or social networks and social capital that receive systematic attention in other SaSR-courses). Systematic reconstructions of social science theory emphasize explanations of macro-phenomena based on micro-models of behaviour and macro-micro-macro transitions. Applications will focus on key problems of sociology (cohesion, inequality, and rationalization), with an emphasis on paradigmatic macro-phenomena related to these problems such as effects of networks and institutional arrangements (organizations) on cohesion, inequality, and rationalization, and, conversely, effects of cohesion, inequality, and rationalization on the dynamics of networks and institutional arrangements. Generating testable hypotheses on macro-phenomena from underlying theory and the ability to assess available literature with respect to the 'performance' of such hypotheses in empirical research is a topic of the course.

column1: Two of the meetings will be done by dr. Jacob Dijkstra, University of Groningen.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174731,2016,Sociology of Migration,English,University College Utrecht,,['dr. W.H. Poppe'],,Course goals
Upon completion of this course, the student will be able to:
Identify the main theories and empirical findings in the study of international migration and&nbsp
apply this knowledge to new problems within the field of international migration and integration
This course offers a comprehensive overview of the key&nbsp
column2: issues in the study of international migration and integration. The perspective in this course is primarily sociological but it also leans heavily on notions from other disciplines such as economics, geography, political science, psychology and anthropology. The course deals with both the theoretical debates in the field and with empirical data and case studies on which these debates hinge. The course not only focuses on migration and its causes as such, but also with phenomena that develop in the aftermath of migration, such as integration and transnationalism.

column1: Students have read the obligatory literature for each meeting and prepare it in an active and analytical way. The teacher will introduce the main themes and coordinates class discussions. The class discussions will be focused on the main questions that have been handed in by the students the day before the class meeting. The role of the teacher is to give feedback when necessary and to make sure that all important issues and questions are properly covered, so that the learning goals of the course are successfully achieved.

The standard model will be that a class meeting starts with a short lecture of the teacher to place the specific theme into context followed by a general discussion based on the main clarification-type and critical questions of the obligatory readings. Since all students have read and critically reviewed the reading material, a lively discussion is to be expected. Subsequently, there will be student presentations of additional empirical studies. The time limit per student presentation is 20 minutes in which the student should summarise the article, discuss the additional insights of the article to the obligatory readings and give a critical reflection. After the student presentations, the clarification-type and critical questions of the obligatory readings will be discussed. Relevant documentaries will be shown and discussed in part of a few class meetings.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171152,2016,Sociology of Organisations,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['drs. S.B. Soeparman', 'J. Pach', 'M. Verhoef, MSc']",,"Course goals
To acquire knowledge about the development and relevance of sociological theories and research on organisations, their structures and functioning, and changes therein.
To be able to discriminate between various theoretical insights (similarities and differences) concerning organizstions.
To obtain a theoretically informed in depth view and understanding of a specific company, through the composition of a portfolio. &nbsp

During most parts of our life, we are embedded in organisations, and their structures and contents have a major effect on our lives. Without knowledge about and insight in modern organizations, we cannot understand many social problems. Scientific theories and research on organisations are multidisciplinary, including economics, management science, geography, political sciences, but also psychology and sociology. This course provides an introduction to various topics central to the sociological understanding of organizations.&nbsp
column2: In this course, important sociological theories and research on organizations will be presented and discussed.

column1: The course is structured around 6 theoretical strands of thought or perspectives (see Watson, 2012 p.33):&nbsp

These perspectives act as lenses through which various topics concerning organizations can be looked upon, and studied, in specific ways. By the end of this course, students will have been exposed to a wide range of core concepts of the sociological field. In this course we will be looking at topics such as&nbsp
column11: power issues in and around organizations. Each week is organized around a specific topic which will be studied in various ways. First, the topic of the week will be addressed in the weekly lecture. Second, the topic will be discussed in the weekly workshop for which students are required to make a preparatory assignment. Third, a specific case relevant to that week’s (and earlier) topic(s) will be studied in the workshop. Fourth, students will work in groups of 3-4 students on a
column13: (CCSP) during the last third of the workshop. This portfolio is intended to apply theory to a particular company. Students are expected to update their portfolio every week after a new topic has been addressed in the lecture and workshop. At the end of the course this cumulative portfolio is graded.&nbsp

column1: Knowledge at the level of the introductory courses (bachelor 1 in social sciences), as well as sound knowledge of the English language is assumed.&nbsp
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171807,2016,Sociology of Religion: Theories and methods,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. P. Tamimi Arab'],,Course goals

Students are expected to: gain     an     overview     of     key     issues     in     the     sociology     of     religion,     master     basic     theories     and     concepts,     are     able     to     apply     these     to     ongoing     public     debates     via     oral     and     written     contributions.

The ""come back"" of religion is subject to much public debate. While church membership and attendance in mainstream Christianity declines in Northern Europe, the evangelical movement thrives. With the arrival of migrant churches, Islamic groups and New Age, the religious field is diversified. All over the world, religious revival movements manifest themselves as major public players, often by making prolific use of the latest media technologies. Scholars agree that secularization theory, which assumed that modernization entails the decline of (the public significance) of religion, has lost its explanatory power. How to develop adequate theories and methods to grasp the place and role of religion in the 21st century is the burning question in the sociology of religion. In the first part, this class introduces foundational thinkers and key concepts, including the rise and critique of secularization theory and post-secular concepts. Exploring the various concrete manifestations of religion in our time (including New Age and the search for spirituality, the rise of transnational Pentecostal and Islamic movements, and the resilience of orthodox forms of Christianity), the second part presents new foci in the contemporary study of religion that help us understand how religions transform via a constant exchange with wider society.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/173615,2016,Soft condensed matter theory,English,Faculty of Science,,['prof. dr. R.H.H.G. van Roij'],,Course goals

• has good working knowledge of thermodynamics and classical Gibbs ensembles, can calculate thermodynamic properties of non-ideal gases from the virial expansion and has a basic understanding of pair correlations and the structure factor of gases, liquids, and crystals
• understands the Ornstein-Zernike equation and its application to hard-sphere fluids, and can calculate macroscopic properties of classical many-body systems from thermodynamic perturbation theory
• knows concepts and theories of surface tension, adsorption, and capillary waves

• understands the concept of effective interactions in the osmotic ensemble, understands the basics of classical density functional theory, and is aware of its relations to the virial expansion and the Ornstein-Zernike equation
• knows the concepts of electrostatic double layers and ionic screening, and can do calculations within Poisson-Boltzmann and Debye-Hückel theory for charged particles or surfaces in electrolytes
• knows scaling properties of ideal and self-avoiding polymer chains and can calculate the universal scaling exponents in the semi-dilute regime of polymer solutions
• has a basic knowledge of the structure and properties of liquid crystalline states of matter, can derive Onsager’s theory for nematic liquid crystals and work with it
• has basic knowledge of nonequilibrium and hydrodynamic phenomena such as shear flow and electrokinetics

<body>Soft matter consists of mesoscopic objects such as colloidal particles, polymer chains, or macromolecules, which are often suspended in a liquid medium, often with addional ions. Traditional examples of such systems are blood, mud, hairgel, yoghurt, or paint, but more recent examples include liquid crystals, photonic bandgap materials, DNA in the living cell, and e-ink.The traditional picture of these systems a ""dirty chemical soup"" is no longer true due to spectacular advances in chemical synthesis and microscopy, resulting in clean and well-defined model systems that can&nbsp
column2: be studied in great detail experimentally. In this course we will discuss the phenomenology of this systems from a theoretical perspective, with a focus on e.g. phase transitions, structure, spontaneous ordering, medium-induced effective interactions, Brownian dynamics. We will develop the theory to interpret, describe and predict physical properties of these systems. A short initial crash-course on classical statistical mechanics (thermodynamic potentials, Legendre transforms, ensembles, partition functions, etc.) will be extended to describe interacting many-body systems (virial expansion, distribution functions, Ornstein-Zernike theory, thermodynamic perturbation theory, van der Waals theory, critical exponents, hard-sphere crystallisation, and density functional theory). Further extensions to describe ionic liquids and colloidal suspensions will be discussed (Debye-Hueckel theory, screening, Poisson-Boltzmann theory, DLVO theory, effective many-body interactions, depletion effect due added polymers, charge renormalization). Also liquid crystals (nematic, smectic, columnar phases, Onsager theory), polymers (random walks, theta collapse, flexibility, persistence length,scaling concepts), interfacial phenomena (adsorption, wetting, surface tension, capillary waves, density profiles, droplets), and (hydro-)dynamic effects (Brownian motion, Langevin equation, dynamic density functional theory) will be covered.</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/173941,2016,Software architecture,English,Faculty of Science,,['dr. ir. J.M.E.M. van der Werf', 'prof. dr. S. Brinkkemper']",,"Content

The course on software architecture deals with the concepts and best practices of software architecture. The focus is on theories explaining the structure of software systems and how system’s elements are meant to interact given the imposed quality requirements.
Technical relations, development life cycle, business profile, and the architect’s professional practices
Quality attributes: availability, modifiability, performance, security, usability, testability, and interoperability
Architecturally significant requirements, and how to determine them
Architectural patterns in relation to architectural tactics
Architecture in the life cycle, including generate-and-test as a design philosophy
Architecture and current technologies, such as the cloud, social networks, and mobile devices
Architecture competence: what this means both for individuals and organizations
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/173994,2016,Software ecosystems,English,Faculty of Science,,['dr. S. Jansen'],,Course goals
The goals of this course are:
To get students intimately familiar with the theory of software ecosystems, specifically management, modeling, and simulation
To get students acquainted with the academic writing and publication process
To contribute to the collection of knowledge on software ecosystems
To show students the cutting edge of science in a field and to provoke thought about future developments
The aim of the seminar is to get students familiar with selected topics on software ecosystems but also to get students familiar with the academic publication process.

vendors no longer function as independent units, where all customers are end-users, where there are no suppliers, and where all software is built in-house. Instead, software vendors have become networked, i.e., software vendors are depending on (communities of) service and software component suppliers, value-added-resellers, and pro-active customers who build and share customizations. Software vendors now have to consider their strategic role in the software ecosystem to survive. With their role in the software ecosystem in mind, software vendors can become more successful by opening up their business, devising new business models, forging long-lasting relationships with partnership networks, and overcoming technical and social challenges that are part of these innovations.

software ecosystem is a set of actors functioning as a unit and interacting with a shared market for software and services, together with the relationships among them. These relationships are frequently underpinned by a common technological platform or market and operate through the exchange of information, resources and artifacts. Several challenges lie in the research area of software ecosystems. To begin with, insightful and scalable modeling techniques for software ecosystems currently do not exist. Furthermore, methods are required that enable software vendors to transform their legacy architectures to accommodate reusability of internal common artifacts and external components and services. Finally, methods are required that support software vendors in choosing survival strategies in software ecosystems.

introduce many new research challenges on both a technical and a business level. In a traditionally closed market, software vendors are now facing the challenge of opening up their product interfaces, their knowledge bases, and in some cases even their software. Software vendors must decide how open their products and interfaces are, new business models need to be developed, and new standards for component and service reuse are required. These challenges have been identified but have hardly been picked up by the research community.

In this seminar topics on SECOs are discussed. These topics can range from consultancy oriented for product software companies to highly technical for software engineers. The course is largely dependent on student participation. Some example topics are:
Keystone and niche player survival strategy
Communities of practice and software reuse
API related topics: design, development, marketing
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/173895,2016,Software product management,English,Faculty of Science,,['Lucassen, MSc', 'prof. dr. S. Brinkkemper']",,"Course goals
At the end of this course, the student has the knowledge and skills to
carry out SPM activities in a software company
perform a scientific research in the SPM domain
assess, analyze and give advice about a company's SPM processes.

The success of a software product depends on skilled and competent software product management (SPM). In essence, a product manager decides what functionality and quality a product should offer, to which customers, and when in time, while assuring a winning business case. Sometimes a product manager is referred to as the 'mini-CEO' of an organization.
The course is built around three pillars: SPM theory, SPM research and SPM consultancy.
